singular  fact,  that  these  charters,  marked  L.  and  M.,  were  obtained  out  of  the  great  mass  of  rubbish 
thrown  into  the  pubhc  streets  when  the  cellare  of  the  Laigh  Parliament  House  were  cleared  out  upwards 
of  forty  years  ago.     Many  others  must,  at  the  same  time,  have  been  destroyed.

HISTORICAL  NOTICES 

OF 

THE  COLLEGIATE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES, 
EDINBURGH. 


HISTORICAL   NOTICES 


COLLEGIATE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES,  EDINBURGH. 


The  Church  of  St.  Giles,  prior  to  the  era  of  the  Keformation, 
although  surpassed  in  wealth  and  architectural  splendour  by  some  other 
religious  establishments  in  Edinburgh,  has  more  than  a  local  interest 
attached  to  its  history.  A  collection  of  the  earlier  charters  connected  with 
this  Metropolitan  Church,  which  has  now  existed  for  upwards  of  seven  cen- 
turies, could  not  therefore  fail  to  form  a  suitable  addition  to  the  several 
Chartularies  already  printed  for  the  Bannatyne  Club.  The  materials  for 
such  a  volume  were  indeed  somewhat  scanty  and  dispersed,  but  there  for- 
tunately exists  a  Register  of  such  deeds,  commenced  in  the  year  1368,  and 
partially  continued  for  upwards  of  a  century.  This  Register,  which  is  a 
square  folio  of  thirty-eight  leaves  of  vellum,  written  at  different  times  and 
by  different  hands,  is  in  the  possession  of  the  Right  Honourable  Lord 
Panmure,  by  whom  the  use  of  it  was  most  liberally  granted.  Such  orio-inal 
charters  as  are  now  preserved  in  the  Archives  of  the  City  of  Edinburgh 
were  communicated  with  equal  liberality  by  the  Lord  Provost  and  Magis- 
trates, who,  at  the  same  time,  permitted  free  access  to  their  Records  for  the 
purpose  of  elucidating  the  history  of  the  Church.  The  collection  has  been 
further  enlarged  with  charters  in  the  possession  of  private  individuals,  and 
with  such  as  are  incorporated  in  some  contemporary  Protocol  books  or  in 
the  Great  Seal  Register.     The  whole  of  these  charters  have  been  arrant^ed 


iv  HISTORICAL  NOTICES  OF 

in  chronological  order,  and  those  prior  to  the  year  1400,  and  such  others 
as  seemed  of  more  than  special  interest,  are  given  without  abridgment. 
While  grateful  thanks  are  due  to  the  several  parties  who  have  contri- 
buted the  use  of  the  necessary  materials  for  this  work,  it  is  but  proper 
to  add,  that  the  details  of  preparing  the  transcripts  for  the  press,  of  abridg- 
ing the  more  recent  charters,  revising  the  text,  and  forming  the  index,  have 
been  assigned  to  Mr.  James  B.  Brichan,  the  editor  of  the  latter  portion  of 
the  Origines  Parochiales  Scotice. 

The  History  of  Edinburgh  is  very  obscure  until  we  reach  the  times 
of  David  the  First,  in  the  twelfth  century.  That  a  parish  church  of  small 
dimensions  may  have  existed  nearly  coeval  with  the  Castle  and  town,  and 
long  antecedent  to  existing  records,  is  at  least  highly  probable.  Symeon 
of  Durham,  who  flourished  in  the  early  part  of  the  thirteenth  century,  under 
the  year  854  includes  Edinburgh  in  reckoning  the  churches  and  towns 
belonging  to  the  Bishopric  of  Lindisfarne  or  Holy  Island,  in  the  district  of 
Northumbria  ;  and  this  See,  previously  to  the  Scoto-Saxon  period,  extended 
over  the  ample  range  of  Lothian  as  well  as  the  more  southern  districts  of 
North  Britain.  This  reference  is^enerally  considered  as  applicable  to  the 
Church  of  St.  Cuthbert  under  the  Castle ;  but  it  is  to  be  remarked,  that 
St.  Cuthbert's  was  always  a  distinct  Church  and  Parish,  and  formed  no  part 
of  Edinburgh,  and  the  name  "  Edwinesburch"  '  must  therefore  have  had  a 
special  reference  to  the  Castle  and  town.  It  was,  however,  only  when 
Malcolm  the  Second,  King  of  Scotland,  about  the  year  1020  obtained  the 
cession  of  Lothian  from  the  Saxon  Earl  Eadulf,  that  this  district,  with  an 
increasing  population,  became  of  importance,  and  it  has  ever  since  remained 
a  part  of  the  kingdom  of  Scotland  :  the  ecclesiastical  jurisdiction  afterwards 
continued  to  be  exercised  by  the  Bishop  of  St.  Andrews,  and  the  assumed 
dependency  upon  the  See  of  York  was  constantly  and  most  resolutely  op- 
posed by  the  Scottish  Church. 

The  Abbey,  founded  by  David  the  First,  in  honour  of  the  Holy  Cross, 

'  Twysdea's  Siat.  Anglic.  Script,  x.  p.  139.     Petrie's  MonumerUa  Hielorica  Britannioa,  p.  675. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  v 

and  the  Virgin  Mary,  and  all  the  Saints,  was  commenced  in  the  year 
1128.  In  the  great  Charter,  which  may  be  dated  about  the  year  1145,  the 
King,  for  the  support  of  this  foundation  for  Canons  Regular  of  the  rule  of 
St.  Augustin,  bestowed  the  Church  of  the  Castle,  the  Church  of  St.  Cuth- 
bert  under  the  Castle  wall,  the  Chapels  of  Corstorphin,  Liberton,  and  vari- 
ous lands,  chiefly  in  the  vicinity  of  Edinburgh.  Had  there  been  a  parish 
church  of  equal  importance  with  that  of  St.  Cuthbert's,  it  might  be  sup- 
posed that  it  would  have  been  mentioned  with  the  other  churches  named  in 
this  Foundation  Charter.  Yet  we  find  that  in  connexion  with  the  parish 
church  there  was  at  that  period  a  farm  to  the  south  of  Edinburgh, 
which,  from  its  being  the  grange  of  the  Vicar  of  St.  Giles's  Church,  was 
called  St.  Giles's  Grange.  It  was  conferred  by  David  the  First  on  the 
monks  of  Holm  Cultram.*  The  name  of  the  Grange  in  that  locality  is  still 
'retained.  Under  the  date  of  1243,  we  find  the  name  of  a  Perpetual  Vicar 
of  the  Church  of  St.  Giles,  Edinburgh  ;  this  circumstance,  along  with  the 
earlier  reference  to  its  Grange,  suggests  that  the  church  must  have  been 
attached  to  some  religious  house,  and  like  the  Priory  of  Coldingham,  it 
might  for  a  time  have  remained  subordinate  to  Lindisfarne.  It  therefore 
seems  the  most  reasonable  conjecture,  that  the  parish  church  dedicated 
in  honour  of  St.  Egidius  or  St.  Giles,  and  which  has  ever  since  retained  the 
name  of  the  patron  saint,  was  erected  during  the  reign  of  Alexander  the 
First  (1107-1124),  the  founder  of  the  Abbey  of  Scone,  and  several  other  reli- 
gious houses.  Edinburgh  at  least  was  a  place  of  suflicient  importance  in  his 
brother  David  the  First's  reign  (1124-1153)  to  be  reckoned  one  of  the  Qua- 
tuor  Burgorum  Principalium,  as  a  judicatory  for  commercial  matters."  The 
other  boroughs  were  Stirling,  Roxburgh,  and  Berwick  ;  and  their  enact- 
ments form  the  earliest  existing  collected  body  of  the  Laws  of  Scotland.' 

A  portion  of  the  original  church,  which,  from  its  style,  may  with  some 
degree  of  confidence  be  assigned  to  the  early  part  of  the  twelfth  century, 

'  "  Monaclii  de  Hareliope,  alias  Holme,  per  recolendic  tona  et  Saxt  Gilysis  Grange." — Forduni  Scotichroni-

existed  within  the  recollection  of  persons  still  alive,  being  a  richly  orna- 
mented Norman  porch,  which  had  formed  the  entrance  to  the  nave  on  the 
north  side  of  the  church.  Fortunately,  before  its  removal  in  the  year  1797 
or  1798,  a  representation  of  it  was  taken  and  etched  by  an  Edinburgh  artist, 
of  which  a  careful  fac-simile  has  been  engraved  as  a  frontispiece  to  this 
volume.^  The  archivolt,  it  will  be  seen,  was  in  several  divisions,  exhibiting 
figures  of  animals  and  grotesque  heads,  along  with  crenelated  and  chevron 
mouldings.  Such  doorways  were  often  preserved,  when  every  other  part 
of  the  church  was  rebuilt.^  Had  it  still  existed,  it  would  liave  formed  the 
most  interesting  specimen  of  early  architecture  in  this  part  of  the  country. 
The  prevalence  of  Norman  remains  among  such  of  the  ancient  parish 
churches  of  the  Lothians  as  still  retain  any  of  their  original  masonry,  proves 
that  a  very  general  impulse  had  been  given  to  ecclesiastical  architecture 
about  the  period  when  the  Abbey  of  Holyrood  was  founded  in  the  twelfth 
century.^  In  confirmation  of  this  remark,  it  might  be  sufficient  to  mention 
the  existing  churches  of  Kirkliston  and  Dalmeny,  and  the  older  portions  of 
that  of  Duddingstone. 

In  the  ancient  Taxation  of  ecclesiastical  benefices,  preserved  in  several 
of  the  chartularies,  without  date,  but  evidently  belonging  to  the  thirteenth 
century,  as  the  rule  by  which  the  Scottish  clergy  were  to  be  assessed  by  the 
Church  of  Rome,  the  Ecclesia  Sancti  Egidii  de  Edinburgh  was  placed  in 
the  Deanery  of  Linlithgow,  and  rated  at  the  annual  value  of  twenty-six 
merks.  This  comparatively  small  assessment  may  be  accounted  for  by  the 
parish  not  extending  beyond  the  boundaries  of  the  town  ;  the  amount  being 
only  one  merk  more  than  the  adjoining  parishes  of  Duddingstone  and  Res- 
talrig,  but  not  one-third  of  that  of  Lasswade,  or  one-sixth  of  St.  Cuthbert's 
(sub  Castro)  under  the  Castle.     The  vicinity  of  the  Abbey  of  Holyrood

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  .      vii 

may  have  likewise  been  the  cause  why  the  borough  of  Edinburgh  was  not 
constituted  the  seat  of  an  Archdeacon.  In  the  Taxation  of  1275,  known 
as  Bagimont  or  Bayamond's  Roll,  St.  Giles  is  rated  at  xvj  li.'  This  sum 
nearly  coincides  with  another  taxation  of  Ecclesiastical  benefices  for  Papal 
tenths  within  the  southern  district  of  Scotland,  preserved  among  the  Re- 
cords of  Durham,  in  a  roll  of  the  early  part  of  Edward  the  First,  in  which 
the  Ecclesia  Sancli  Egidii  is  estimated,  verus  valor,  at  vj  li.  xiij  s.  iiij  d.,  and 
Vicaria  ejusdem  at  x  li. ;  the  Decima  respectivelybeing  xiij  s.  iiij  d.  and 
XX  s.^ 

This  ancient  Church  of  St.  Giles,  consisting  of  a  nave  and  chancel, 
with  small  side  aisles,  may  have  either  been  rebuilt,  retaining  the  orna- 
mented porch,  or  only  been  completed  in  the  course  of  the  thirteenth  cen- 
tury. Notwithstanding  the  ravages  committed  by  the  invading  forces  of 
England,  and  the  successive  alterations  and  improvements,  not  less 
destructive,  it  can  scarcely  be  said  ever  to  have  been  wholly  demolished, 
although  its  Norman  character  gradually  disappeared  as  the  church  was 
enlarged,  and  numerous  chapels  and  aisles  were  added,  thus  including  the 
work  of  many  different  periods ;  but  no  part  of  the  architecture  now  indi- 
cates an  earlier  date  than  the  latter  part  of  the  thirteenth  century.  As 
usual  in  all  large  churches,  it  presented  internally  the  form  of  a  cross, 
with  the  central  tower  placed  at  the  junction  of  the  nave  and  choir,  with 
transepts  and  aisles  both  south  and  north. 

During  the  minority  of  David  the  Second,  the  infant  heir  of  King 
Robert  the  First,  who  died  in  1329,  Edinburgh  was  exposed  to  constant  de- 
predations in  the  contests  with  England  and  the  adherents  of  Edward  Balliol. 
That  the  parish  church  did  not  escape  the  ravages  of  the  English  invaders 
is  stated  by  some  of  our  older  historians.  The  Chartulary  of  St.  Giles, 
now  printed,  in  fact  commences  with  an  exordium,  dated  on  the  Tuesday 
following  the  feast  of  St.  Michael  the  Archangel  (29th  September)  1368,

to  this  effect : — That  the  Aldermen  and  Bailies  of  Edinburgh,  taking  into

altars  endowed  therein  by  burgesses,  had  been  abstracted  or  misapplied,  to 
the  diminution  of  Divine  worship,  they,  with  the  consent  and  assent  of  the

quests," the  list  mentioned  only  specifies  ten  charters,  of  dates  between 
1346  and  1363,  and  no  deeds  of  an  earlier  date  have  been  preserved. 

In  the  spring  of  1383,  John  of  Gaunt,  Duke  of  Lancaster,  came  to 
Edinburgh,  but  restrained  his  forces  from  sacking  or  destroying  the  town, 
the  citizens  having,  according  to  Wyntoun,  saved  it  by  ransom.  In  the 
subsequent  invasion,  the  English  army  under  Richard  the  Second,  in  1385, 
again  took  possession  of  Edinburgh,  but  after  they  had  occupied  the  town 
for  five  days,  it  was  committed  to  the  flames.  All  our  old  historians  concur 
in  stating  that  while  the  Abbey  of  Holyrood  escaped  at  this  time,  St.  Giles's 
Church  was  involved  in  the  general  conflagration  of  the  town.  Thus 
Andrew  of  Wyntoun,  in  his  Metrical  Clironicle,  says  that  the  English 
forces,  after  burning  the  Abbeys  of  Melrose  and  Dryburgh,

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  ix 

EJUSDEM  voraci  flamnia  incineravit."  In  tracing  the  history  of  the  Church  of 
St.  Giles,  three  epochs  are  thus  distinctly  marked.  The  first  is  that  to  which 
we  have  referred,  when  it  was  of  limited  extent  and  size  ;  and  the  roof  and 
other  portions  being  probably  of  timber,  were  consumed,  while  the  deco- 
rated Norman  porch,  with  the  massive  stone  piers  and  arches  of  the  nave 
and  of  the  chancel,  may  have  only  been  partially  injured,  and  not  wholly 
destroyed  like  the  wooden  houses,  thatched  with  straw,  of  which,  according 
to  Froissart's  description,  the  town  chiefly  consisted. 

An  original  document  of  the  period  is  fortunately  preserved,  and  serves 
to  illustrate  the  actual  state  and  progressive  enlargement  of  the  Church 
of  St.  Giles  in  what  may  be  called  the  second  epoch  of  its  history.  It  is 
the  contract  between  the  Provost  and  community  of  Edinburgh  on  the  one 
part,  and  John  Prymros,  John  of  Scone,  and  John  Skuyer,  masons,  on  the 
other  part,  by  which  they  engage  to  erect  five  vaulted  chapels  on  the  south 
side  of  the  parish  church  of  Edinburgh,  from  the  west  gavel,  lying  "  in 
rayndoun"  (signifying,  probably,  in  a  straight  line)  eastward  to  the  great 
pillar  of  the  steeple,  in  the  same  style  of  masonry  as  the  vault  above  St. 
Stephen's  altar,  erected  on  the  north  side  of  the  parish  kirk  of  the  Abbey 
of  Holyrood.  Four  of  these  chapels  were  each  to  have  a  window  of  three 
lights;  and  the  fifth  chapel  was  to  have  a  door  equal  to,  or  corresponding 
with,  the  west  door  of  the  church.  The  contract  is  in  the  following 
terms  : —

An  important  fact  may  be  deduced  from  the  above  contract,  as  it  is 
evident  from  these  stipulations  that  the  nave  of  the  church,  extending  to 
the  pillars  of  the  great  steeple,  was  entire,  and  had  escaped  the  eiFects  of  the 
conflagration  in  the  year  1385. 

This  contract,  dated  29th  November  1387,  which  presents  one  of  the 
earliest  specimens  of  Scottish  prose  now  extant,'  is  peculiarly  interesting 
in  connexion  with  ecclesiastical  architecture.  The  sum  stipulated  to  be 
paid  to  the  masons  was  GOO  merks  of  sterlings  of  the  payment,  or  money,of 
Scotland  ;  and  on  the  back  of  the  contract"  is  the  acknowledgment  of  the 
builders  having  received,  in  1390,  twelve  score  pounds  sterling,  and,  in 
August  1391,  a  further  payment  of  ninety-two  pounds,  leaving  a  balance  of 
the  stipulated  sum  as  still  due  of  £2G8.  The  work  was  evidently  still  in 
progress ;  but  whether  the  sums  paid  to  John  Prymros,  one  of  the  masons, 
in  1399  and  1402,  recorded  among  the  miscellaneous  notices  at  the  end  of 
the  chartulary,  formed  part  of  the  first  contract,  must  be  left  to  conjecture. 
An  examination  of  the  form  of  the  groining  clearly  indicates  that  the  outer 
walls  of  both  the  south  and  north  aisles  of  the  original  church  had  been  taken 
down  and  rebuilt,  and  new  vaulted  roofs  substituted.     At   this  period,  the

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GH^ES.  xi 

nave  had  no  clere-story,  which,  as  it  now  exists  in  the  western  portion  of  the 
buildintr,  is  a  modern  addition,  of  lathe  and  plaster,  in  imitation  of  stone. 

In  the  plan  of  the  church,  these  chapels  are  marked  i  1  to  5,  and 
the  porch  or  door,  a.  In  recent  times  this  vaulted  porch,  with  its  richly 
o-roined  ceiling,  served  as  the  south  entrance  to  the  Tolbooth  Church  ;  and 
over  it  was  a  small  chamber,  lighted  by  an  oriel  window,  the  corbel  of  which 
was  an  angel  holding  the  city  arms.  This  apartment,  from  its  contiguity  to 
the  Council  Chambers,  was  long  used  as  a  charter-room,  and  immediately 
above  it  was  another  small  room  or  closet,  having  some  old-fashioned  oak 
cabinets,  also  filled  with  a  mass  of  deeds,  papers,  and  city  records.  Its  en- 
trance latterly  was  from  the  pulpit-stair  within  the  church.  It  was  originally 
the  Revestry,  or  room  for  holding  the  vestments  of  the  clergy,  but  being  no 
longer  required  for  such  a  purpose,  it  was  employed,  by  order  of  the  Coun- 
cil, for  "keeping  of  their  Evidentis  buikis,"  &c.  This  was  in  April  15G3.' 
But  this  porch  and  chamber,  as  well  as  the  two  chapels  marked  b  4  and  b  5, 
without  the  least  regard  to  old  associations  or  to  picturesque  effect,  and 
although  in  perfect  preservation,  after  a  lapse  of  more  than  four  centuries, 
were  most  ruthlessly  sacrificed  in  order  to  obtain  the  tame  formality  of  the 
present  exterior. 

King  Robert  the  Third,  in  consequence  of  the  injury  which  the  church 
sustained  in  1385,  may  have  been  led  by  public  grants  to  aid  in  its  restora- 
tion and  enlargement.  In  the  Chamberlain  Rolls,  between  the  years  1390 
and  1398,  various  annual  sums  are  allocated,  conceduntur  per  Regem  ad 
fabricam  Ecclesie  Beati  Egidii  de  Edinburgh.  During  the  minority  and 
captivity  of  James  the  First  in  England,  the  same  record  exhibits  similar 
grants  between  1409  and  1413,  ex  donacione  Domini  Gubernatoris  (Robert 
Duke  of  Albany),  ad  fabricam  Ecclesie  parochialis  burgi  de  Edinburgh.^ 

It  thus  appears  that  the  Church  of  St.  Giles,  like  almost  every  large 
fabric  of  the  kind,  was  a  work  continued  for  many  generations,  and  enlarged 
by  public  as  well  as  private  contributions.  At  a  somewhat  later  period  than 
the  five  chapels  commenced  in  1387,  a  similar  range  of  small  chapels  on  the 
north  side  were  erected,  two  on  each  side  of  the  old  Norman  porch.     The  two

western  chapels  still  remain  with  a  light  and  elegant  clustered  pillar,  from  the 
capital  of  which  spring  the  ribs  of  the  groined  roof,  and  the  arches  that 
divide  it  from  the  adjoining  aisle.  The  accompanying  woodcut  gives  a  view 
of  this  part  of  the  church,  being  one  of  the  few  portions  which  were  allowed 
to  remain  almost  untouched  ;  but  forming  part  of  the  north  gallery  of  the 
church  now  called  West  St.  Giles,  it  was  not  thought  necessary  to  encumber 
the  sketch  with  the  gallery  and  under-pews,  or  to  represent  the  barbarous 
manner  in  which  the  bases  of  the  pillars  have  been  hewn  away. 


In  the  ground-plan  of  the  church,  the  above  centre  pillar,  marked  q,  is 
called  the  Albany  pillar,  from  having  on  its  capital  two  shields  of  arms. 
The  shield  on  the  south  side  of  the  pillar,  contains  the  armorial  bearing  of

Robert,  Duke  of  Albany,  the  second  son  of  King  Robert  the  Second  ;  the 
other,  on  the  north  side,  of  Archibald,  fourth  Earl  of  Douglas.^ 


Duke  of  Albany. 


Earl  of  Douglas. 


An  incident  related  by  Bovver  in  his  Scotichronicon,  under  the  year 
1416,  seems  to  indicate  that  the  building  of  the  church  was  completed,  so  far 
as  the  design  of  that  time  extended.  "  Hoc  etiam  anno  par  avium  ciconi- 
arum  venerunt  in  Scotiam,  et  super  ecclesiam  S.  ^^gidii  de  Edinburgh 
nidificabant,  et  per  unam  ratam  anni  ibi  morabantur ;"-  but  with  some  sim- 
plicity it  is  added,  "  sed  quo  postea  avolaverunt  nescitur."  It  needs  scarcely 
be  remarked,  that  storks  were  not  likely  to  build  their  nests  on  a  church 
where  masons  were  still  at  work.  It  is  highly  probable  that  a  small  Lady 
Chapel  may  have  existed  at  the  east  end  of  the  church,  but  been  removed 
when  the  building  was  enlarged. 

The  third  period  of  the  history  of  the  church  may  be  dated  from  the 
middle  of  the  fifteenth  century,  when  the  choir  had  been  enlarged  and  com- 
pleted, by  extending  the  building  eastward  in  its  present  form.  At  the  same 
time  the  roof  was  raised,  and  the  clere-story  windows  added.  That  it  was 
thus  enlarged  appears  not  only  from  the  more  ornate  style  of  the  building, 
but  from  the  appearance  of  the  walls,  marking  distinctly  the  older  portions, 
and  also  from  the  heraldic  devices  and  armorial  bearings  still  existing.  Thus 
it  is  evident  that  while  the  pillars  nearest  to  the  centre  are  plain  octatfons, 
with  arches  corresponding  in  simplicity,  those  at  the  east  end  have  decorated 
capitals  supporting  moulded  arches.  There  is  a  change  also  in  the  groining 
of  the  aisles,  and  the  spaces  between  the  pier-arches  are  enlarged.^     The

King's  pillar,  as  it  is  called,  is  the  first  from  the  window  on  the  north  side, 
and  near  the  spot  where  stood  the  High  Altar.  On  the  foliated  capital  are 
four  coats  of  arms,  two  of  which,  the  second  and  third,  are  here  represented. 


Of  these  armorial  bearings,  the  first  has  the  lion  within  the  double  tres- 
sure,  and  is  usually  supposed  to  be  those  of  King  James  the  Second  (1436- 
1460);  the  second,  impaled,  of  his  Queen,  Mary  of  Gueldres  (1449-14(33). 
In  both  these  shields  a  blank  space  occurs,  the  upper  part  being  apparently 
left  unfinished,  but  as  this  form  elsewhere  occurs,  it  may  perhaps  have  some 
heraldic  signification.  The  third,  as  above,  has  also  the  lion  within  the 
double  tressure,  but  having  a  label  of  three  points,  which  is  held  to  denote 
a  prince  or  heir,  if  not  a  younger  son.  The  fourth  shield  has  three  fleurs- 
de-lys,  for  France.

Kennedy.  Otterburn. 

On  the  opposite  pillar,  on  the  south  side  of  the  High  Altar,  are  also 
four  coats  of  arms,  viz.,  those  of  the  town  of  Edinburgh,  and  of  the  families 
of  Kennedv,  Otterburn,  and  Preston. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES. 


To  commemorate  other  benefactors,  on  the  demi-pillar,  on  the  north 
side  of  the  eastern  window,  we  have  the  arms,  three  cranes  gorged,  of  Thomas 
Cranstoun,  a  burgess,  and  chief  magistrate  of  Edinburgh  in  1439,  and  again 
in  1454  ;  and  on  the  south  side,  those  of  Napier  of  Merchiston,  also  Provost 
of  tfie  City  in  1457,  on  the  Lennox  shield,  a  saltire  engrailed,  cantoned  with 
four  rosettes,  which  the  Napier   family  assumed  before  the  middle  of  the 


fifteenth  century.^  But  a  circumstance  occurred  which  led  to  the  proposed 
erection  of  the  Preston  Aisle,  on  the  south  side  of  the  church,  in  the  year 
1454. 

In  noticing  this  erection,  we  may  briefly  advert  to  the  Saint  who,  from 
some  unexplained  cause,  was  chosen  by  the  burgesses  of  Edinburgh  as 
their  tutelar  Saint.  St.  Egidius,  or  Giles,  an  Abbot  who  flourished  towards 
the  end  of  the  seventh  century,  according  to  the  recognised  authorities  in 
such  matters,  was  an  Athenian  by  birth,  and  of  noble  extraction.  His 
extraordinary  piety  and  learning  drew  the  admiration  of  the  world  upon 
him  in  such  a  manner,  that  it  was  impossible  for  him  to  enjoy  in  his  own 
country  that  obscurity  and  retirement  which  were  the  chief  object  of  his 
desires  on  earth.^  Having  sailed  for  France,  he  spent  many  years  in  the 
wild  deserts  near  the  mouth  of  the  Ehone,  and  afterwards  in  a  forest  in  the

died,  and  that  his  body  remained  there  till  the  thirteenth  century,  "  when, 
the  Albigenses  being  very  troublesome  in  that  country,  it  was  thought  pro- 
per to  remove  it  to  Toulouse,  where  it  is  still  kept  in  St.  Saturnius'  Church. 
.  His  name  occurs  on  the  1st  of  September  in  the  Calendars  of  the

supported  by  spiral  columns,  a  full  length  figure  of  St.  Giles  with  the  nimbus,

cumstance to  which  we  referred,  as  having  led  to  the  further  enlargement  of 
the  church  was  connected  with  a  relique  of  the  Patron  Saint.

Lords  of  France,  succeeded  in  obtaining  possession  of  the  arm-bone  of  St. 
Giles  ;  and  that  this  inestimable  relique  had  been  freely  bequeathed  by  him

It  may  have  been  to  aid  in  discharging  this  obligation,  that  the  Pro- 
vost and  Council,  in  the  year  1462,  when  they  passed  a  Statute  regarding 
the  mode  of  selling  victual  and  timber,  brought  by  strangers  to  the  port 
of  Leith,  enacted,  that  "  any  person  who  brekis  this  Statute  sail,  pay  to  the 
Kirk  Wark  of  St.  Geill,  ilk  persoun  singularlie  be  himself,  ane  chalder  of 
quheit,  but  remissioun."  In  like  manner,  a  previous  enactment  in  1438 
mav  have  had  some  reference  to  the  enlargement  of  the  church.  But  in  the 
present  remodelled  state  of  the  building,  we  have  no  sure  means  of  assigning 
the  several  divisions  to  their  respective  dates.  Such  work  proceeded  slowly, 
the  number  of  persons  employed  was  limited,  and  the  ornamental  parts  and 
mouldings  were  usually  executed  by  the  Master  Mason  himself.  We  can 
therefore  only  offer  as  a  probable  conjecture,  that  the  same  workmen  who 
extended  the  chancel,  and  added  the  clere-story  the  whole  length  from  the 
pillars  of  the  central  tower  to  the  east  end  of  the  choir,  were  employed  in 
completing  the  Preston  Aisle.  All  this  was  accomplished,  we  may  suppose, 
prior  to  the  year  1475,  when  the  parish  church  had  been  converted  into  a 
collegiate  foundation. 

To  the  same  period  also  may  be  assigned  the  Steeple  or  Airy  Lantern, 
formed  by  cross  ribs,  in  the  shape  of  a  crown  (although  this  in  part  was  pro- 
bably of  a  later  date),  which,  from  its  elevated  position,  rising  in  bold  relief 
against  the  sky,  near  the  centre  of  the  long  line  of  buildings  of  the  old  town, 
covering  the  ridge  from  the  Castle  to  the  Netherbow  Port,  was  always  a  con- 
spicuous and  picturesque  feature  in  any  view  of  the  town.^  An  admirable 
representation  of  the  Tower  and  Lantern  Is  given  in  Billings's  Baronial  and 
Ecclesiastical  Antiquities  of  Scotland,  vol.  il.  His  technical  or  professional 
description  may  be  quoted  : — • 

"  The  general  plan  of  the  church  is  a  cross,  the  lantern-tower  spring- 
ing from  the  meeting  of  the  arms.  Continuous  with  the  extremity  of  the 
nave  is  an  additional  transept  with  a  flat  roof.  The  main  transept  has 
aisles,  and  the  southern  branch  has  projecting  edifices  on  either  side,  which 
give  It  in  Itself  the  form  of  a  cross.    .    .    .    This  species  of  lantern,  formed 

'  Its  e£fect  is  now  less  striking  since  the  erection  of  the  lofty  spire*  of  the   Assembly   Hall  and   of  the 
Tron  Church. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  xix 

by  cross  ribs,  as  in  groined  arching,  seems  to  be  peculiar  to  the  north  of 
Britain.  It  does  not  occur  further  south  than  Newcastle,  while  in  Scotland, 
we  find  it  still  remaining  in  King's  College,  Aberdeen,  and  the  Tron  Steeple 
in  Glasgow  ;  until  lately  it  existed  in  Linlithgow,  and  formerly  terminated 
the  Tower  of  Haddington.  Of  all  the  Scottish  instances,  St.  Giles  is  at  once 
the  richest  and  lightest.  The  others  had  merely  been  formed  by  crossed 
arches  springing  from  the  corbels  of  the  tower.  That  of  St.  Giles  has  an 
octagonal  character,  from  two  arches  springing  from  the  centres  of  the  wall- 
plates.  Along  the  intermediate  spaces  there  is  a  parapet,  pierced  with 
quatrefoils,  having  a  flowered  moulding  at  the  projection,  and  cusps  on  the 
upper  edge.  The  outer  edges  of  the  arches  are  adorned  with  crocketed 
pinnacles,  and  supported  by  the  general  keystone,  there  springs  from  the 
centre  of  a  clustre  of  small  pinnacles,  rising  tier  over  tier,  a  graceful  spire. 
The  whole  plau  exhibits  those  capricious  irregularities  so  frequently  to  be 
found  in  the  finest  specimens  of  Gothic  work." 

To  the  same  period  we  may  refer  the  great  bell  of  St.  Giles,  which 
must  have  been  heard  far  and  near  on  special  occasions  ;  as  when,  after 
news  arriving  of  the  disastrous  field  of  Floddon,  the  inhabitants  were  ordered, 
at  the  tolling  of  the  common  bell,  to  assemble  in  military  array  for  the 
defence  of  the  city.  This  bell  was  cast  in  Flanders,  and  is  described 
having  the  arms  of  Guelderland  upon  diff'erent  parts,  together  with 
figures  of  the  Virgin  and  child,  and  other  devices,  and  had  the  following 
inscription  : — "  Honokabiles  viri  burgenses  Vill.e  de  Edinburgh  in 
Scotia  hanc  Campanam  fieri  fecerunt  Anno  Dni.  m.cccc.lvv.  [1460?]

From  the  Council  Records  towards  the  close  of  the  fifteenth  century, 
and  the  early  part  of  the  sixteenth,  we  learn  that  various  fines  were  still 
directed  to  be  appropriated  to  the  Kirk  wark  of  St.  Giles,  including  the 
reparation  of  altars.  Thus  in  the  Seal  of  Cause  granted  to  the  Incorpora- 
tion of  Fleschers,  11th  of  April  1488,  certain  penalties  were  to  be  exacted, 
two  parts  to  be  raised  by  the  town's  officers  "  to  the  kirk  wark,"  and  the 
third  part  by  the  deacon  of  their  craft,  to  the  reparation  of  their  own  altar 
within  the  church.  But  there  is  one  contract  of  the  Provost  and  Council 
in  the  year  1491,  which  is  worthy  of  special  notice.  This  curious  document, 
which  contains  regulations  for  the  hours  of  attendance  of  the  Master  Mason, 
and  his  colleagues  and  servants,  hitherto  unnoticed,  is  as  follows : —

xx"^  mark  of  fie."  That  some  extensive  operations  were  in  progress  when 
these  regulations  were  enacted,  seems  beyond  doubt.  So  far  as  can  now  be 
ascertained,  the  latest  additions  to  the  church  may  have  included  an  exten- 
sion of  the  south  transept,  and  the  erection  of  the  two  aisles  or  chapels  on 
each  side,  marked  g  and  d  on  the  ground-plan.  The  latter  was  connected 
with  the  south  wall  of  the  chapels  of  1387  marked  h  1  and  b  2,  and  had  a 
groined  roof,  which  was  fully  as  rich  as  any  portion  of  the  choir.  This  was 
the  chapel  referred  to  in  the  Charter  of  Confirmation  of  a  mortification  by 
Sir  Alexander  Lauder  of  Blyth,  Provost  of  Edinburgh,  to  an  altarage  of 
St.  Giles's  Kirk,  dated  l7tb  of  August  1513,  by  which  he  founded  "a  chap- 
lainry  in  the  New  Chapel,  near  the  south-western  corner  of  the  church,  in 
honour  of  God,  the  Virgin  Mary,  and  Gabriel  the  Archangel."  It  consisted 
of  two  arches,  extending  between  the  south  porch  of  1387,  and  the  south 
transept ;  and  in  the  interior  of  the  wall,  between  the  two  windows,  an 
altar-tomb  was  constructed  under  a  deep  recess,  on  which  a  recumbent  figure 
had  no  doubt  been  originally  placed.^  On  each  side  of  the  centre  ornament, 
at  the  top,  but  placed  against  the  wall,  there  appears  like  heraldic  support- 
ers, the  lion  rampant  and  the  dragon. 

The  Church  of  St.  Giles  stood  in  the  centre  of  the  town,  having  the 
Via  Regia  or  High  Street  on  the  north,  and  an  open  space  towards  the 
south,  beyond  the  churchyard,  which  was  afterwards  converted  to  the  same 
purpose.  But  the  church,  from  an  early  period,  was  blocked  up  by  succes- 
sive erections,  originating  in  the  circumscribed  limits  of  the  town  within 
its  walls.  The  "  buith  raw"  was  a  range  of  houses  running  parallel  on 
the  north  side  of  the  church;  and  the  magistrates  derived  an  annual 
revenue   from    the   booths    and   shops    erected   against   the    walls    of  the

The  covered  passage  which  so  long  retained  its  appropriate  name  of 
the  "Stinking  Style,"  in  the  "Booth  Row,"  or  Luckenbooths, ^  served  as 
a  communication  between  the  north  side  of  the  church,  and  the  part  of  the 
principal  street  called  the  Lawnmarket.  At  the  north-east  corner  there 
were  steps  leading  to  the  entrance  of  the  church,  called  "  Our  Lady's  Steps," 
from  the  image  of  the  Virgin,  placed  in  a  niche  of  the  outer  wall.^  Near 
the  same  spot  stood  the  City  Cross.  It  was  removed  and  rebuilt  somewhat 
lower  down  the  High  Street  in  the  year  I6l7.*  In  a  letter  to  Cardinal 
Wolsey  from  Dr.  Magnus,  26th  of  November  1524,  an  account  is  given  of 
the  Earl  of  Angus,  with  a  numerous  retinue,  forcing  his  way  into  Edin- 
burgh, and  "  at  thair  cummying  to  the  Crosse,  beside  Sanct  Giles  Church, 
they  did  proclamations  to  be  made,"  &c.^ 

The  place  which  is  now  called  the  Parliament  Close  was  anciently  the 
churchyard  of  St.  Giles,  being  the  common  cemetery  of  the  town,  as  usual 
attached  to  the  parish  church.  The  Provost's  house,  with  its  garden  or 
glebe,  was  on  the  east  side  ;  the  houses  of  the  prebendaries  and  ministers 
were  on  the  west  side  ;  and  the  declivity  on  the  south  side,  afterwards  fami- 
liarly known  as  "  the  Back  Stairs,"  became  the  lower  churchyard,  at  the  foot

The  survey  of  Edinburgh,  drawn  by  James  Gordon,  minister  of  Rothie- 
may,  in  1647,  and  engraved  in  Holland,  is  of  great  importance  as  the  earli- 
est correct  plan  of  the  city ;  and  that  portion  of  it  showing  St.  Giles,  and 

the  projecting  tops  of  the  Parliament  House, 
then  erected,  is  here  added.  A  considerable 
part  of  the  ground  to  the  south  of  the  church 
was  then  occupied  by  these  new  buildings ; 
and  the  steeple  and  roof  of  the  church  had 
recently  been  restored.  We  could  have 
wished  that  Gordon  had  devoted  more  of  his 
time  to  delineations  of  the  ecclesiastical  build- 
ings as  they  existed  in  his  time,  with  the  same 
fidelity  that  characterizes  the  four  views  of 
public  buildings  in  Edinburgh,  which  were 
also  engraved  in  Holland,  from  his  drawings.^  Views  of  a  later  date  are 
too  common  or  well  known  to  require  any  notice  in  this  place. 


Having  thus  attempted,  in  this  general  description,  to  trace  the  pro- 
gress of  the  building  as  it  existed  prior  to  the  Reformation,  our  attention 
may  now  be  turned  to  the  internal  affairs  of  the  church,  by  presenting  some 
notices  of  its  Dignitaries  and  chief  Benefactors,  interspersed  with  occasional 
references  to  such  public  events  as  in  some  measure  were  connected  with 
its  history.

of  St.  Giles  was  under  the  parochial  charge  of  a  Perpetual  Vicar.  Mention

designation  of  Vicar,  and  the  donation  of  the  grange  or  place  in  which  the 
great  tithes  were  usually  stored,  clearly  denote  that  the  church  itself  must 
for  a  time  have  been  attached  to  some  religious  house  or  monastery. 

The  Parish  Church  of  Edinburgh  was  occasionally  used  for  holding 
national  Councils,  and  other  solemn  meetings.  In  the  year  1293,  a  General 
Council  was  held  in  full  consistory,  in  pleno  consistorio,  within  the  Church 
of  St.  Giles.'  Four  years  later,  on  Sunday  before  the  feast  of  St.  Thomas 
in  1297,  Doneca,  daughter  of  John,  son  of  Herveus,  resigned  certain  lands  to 
the  Convent  of  Holyrood,  in  full  consistory,  held  in  the  Church  of  St.  Giles." 

In  a  charter  granted  by  Sir  David  de  Grahame  to  the  Hospital  of  Soltra, 
Master  Alexander  of  Reclynetoun,  Perpetual  Vicar  of  Edinburgh,  ap- 
pears as  a  witness.^  This  was  probably  in  the  reign  of  Robert  the  First 
(1306-1329),  as  the  charter  was  granted  when  Symon  de  Wedale  was  Abbot 
of  Holyrood,  and  Symon  occurs  as  Abbot  on  the  vigil  of  St.  Barnabas  the 
Apostle  in  1326.'

church,  the  earliest  benefactors  recorded  belong  to  the  middle  of  the  four- 
teenth century.  Among  these  were  Mathias,  son  of  Juliana,  burgess,  in  the 
year  1345  ;  Henry  Multerer,  of  his  lands  of  Grothill,  in  1350,  confirmed 
in  1362  by  his  son,  Robert  Multerer  ;  John  of  Allyncrum,  William  Hare, 
Roger  Hog,  and  other  burgesses  of  Edinburgh.  Some  earlier  grants  may  be 
included  in  the  rental  of  the  several  altars ;'  but  as  the  charters  have  not 
been  preserved,  the  dates  cannot  be  ascertained.  In  1362,  David  the  Second 
confirms  the  grants  of  the  lands  of  Over  Merchiston,  of  Railtoun  or  Ravels- 
toun,  and  of  Craigcruik,  granted  by  William  More,  Lord  of  Abyrcorn,^  Sir 
Patrick  de  Grahame  of  Kynpunt,  and  Sir  David  de  Graham  of  Doundaff,  and 
others.  In  one  of  these  charters,  dated  in  1362-3,  we  find  the  name  of 
DoMiNus  Bricius,  Perpetual  Vicar  of  Edinburgh. 

In  the  year  1384,  the  Scottish  Barons  met  in  St.  Giles's  Church.  This 
circumstance  is  stated  byFroissart,  who  says  that  "the  Earl  of  Douglas,  the 
Earl  Muref,  and  other  knightes  and  squyers  of  Scotland,  helde  a  secret  con 
sayle  togyther  in  the  chiirche  of  Edinhorowe  ;  when  the  said  knights  and 
barons  of  Scotland,  and  they  of  France,  made  an  appointment  to  invade  the 
realme  of  England,  without  the  knowledge  of  the  King  of  Scottes,  who  was 
at  Edenborowe."'  In  prosecution  of  this  enterprise,  they  overran  North- 
umberland, and  committed  great  devastations,  which  in  the  following  year 
were  amply  repaid  when,  as  already  stated,  St.  Giles's  Church  suffered  in 
the  conflagration  by  which  a  great  part  of  the  town  was  destroyed. 

In  the  year  1393  Mr.  James  Lyoun  was  Vicar  of  St.  Giles.  After 
the  Scottish  Church  had  renounced  the  pretended  jurisdiction  of  the  Arch- 
bishops of  York,  the  patronage  of  various  churches  in  the  district  of  Lothian 
probably  remained  vested  in  the  King;  and  Robert  the  Third,  on  the  15th 
of  December  in  that  year,  in  consideration  of  the  expenses  incurred  by  the 
Monastery  of  Scone,  from  its  being  close  to  the  seat  of  Government,  and  thus 
exposed  to  great  charges  in  entertaining  assemblages  of  nobles  at  the  time  of

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  xxvii 

his  coronation,  and  on  other  occasions,  when  met  for  the  transaction  of  urgent 
business,  conferred  the  right  of  patronage  of  the  Church  of  St.  Giles,  and 
every  other  right  which  he  or  his  predecessors  had  in  the  said  church,  on 
that  monastery.  This  grant  was  confirmed  by  Walter  Traill,  Bishop,  and 
the  Chapter  of  St.  Andrews,  on  the  3d  of  May  1395  ;  by  which  union  it  was 
appointed  that  when  Mr.  James  Lyoun  the  Vicar  of  St.  Giles  shall  have 
ceased,  by  death  or  otherwise,  to  hold  the  benefice,  the  canons  of  the  monas- 
tery should  enter  on  possession  of  the  church,  keep  it  in  repair,  and  supply 
it  with  ecclesiastical  services.  In  the  same  year  two  Papal  Bulls  of  Bene- 
dict XIII.  confirmed  the  arrangement  by  which  the  Church  of  St.  Giles 
became  a  dependency  on  Scone.  Although  we  do  not  meet  with  the  name 
of  any  Vicar  of  the  church  for  nearly  half  a  century,  the  Canons  of  Scone 
no  doubt  fulfilled  their  obligations. 

Among  other  important  transactions  of  which  the  Church  of  St.  Giles 
was  the  scene,  it  is  recorded  that  in  the  year  1440,  the  Lord  Chancellor 
Crichton,  and  Sir  Thomas  Livingstone,  Eegent  during  the  minority  of 
James  the  Second,  met  there  to  deliberate  as  to  the  custody  of  the  King's 
person.  It  also  continued  during  the  fifteenth  century  to  receive  many  valu- 
able endowments  from  ecclesiastics  of  distinction  as  well  as  burgesses  ;  in 
particular,  the  names  may  be  specified  of  John  Cameron,  Bishop  of  Glasgow, 
and  Chancellor  of  Scotland  ;  Thomas  of  Cranstoun,  burgess  of  Edinburgh, 
his  wife  Mariot,  and  his  son  "William  of  Cranstoun  ;  the  Forresters  of  Cor- 
storphine  ;  John  Gray,  Eector  of  Kirkliston  ;  John  Laing,  King's  Treasurer,

Merchiston  ;  and  John  Otterburn,  Official  of  Lothian  and  Archdeacon  of 
Galloway.  Had  all  the  charters  and  deeds  of  foundation  been  recorded,  we 
should  no  doubt  have  met  with  the  names  of  other  distinguished  benefactors, 
and  ascertained  the  precise  dates  or  the  occasion  on  which  some  of  the 
chapels  or  aisles  were  erected.

burgh  of  whom  we  find  any  record.  Like  many  of  the  beneficed  clergy  of 
that  period,  he  filled  successively  several  important  offices.  He  was  educated 
at  St.  Andrews,  and  from  the  records  of  the  University  it  appears  that 
Dominus  Johannes  de  Methven  became  a  Bachelor  of  Arts  in  1430,  and  a 
Master  of  Arts  in  1431.  In  1437,  his  name  occurs  as  Provost  of  the  Col- 
legiate Church  of  Lynclouden.  In  1449,  he  is  styled  Doctor  of  Decrees, 
and  was  Master  of  the  Rolls  and  Clerk  Register.  In  the  Parliament  held 
29th  January  1449-50,  the  Vicar  of  Edinburgh,  without  having  his  name 
specified,  was  appointed  one  of  twelve  persons  of  distinction  who  were  chosen 
to  examine  and  report  on  all  Acts  of  Parliament  and  of  General  Council.' 
In  the  following  year,  on  the  5th  of  July,  Dr.  Methven  is  expressly  called 
Vicar  of  Edinburgh  ;^  and  on  the  21st  of  May  1454,  a  safe-conduct  was 
granted  to  John  Methven,  Doctor  of  Decrees,  and  Vicar  of  Edinburgh, 
with  twelve  persons,  to  pass  through  England  and  proceed  to  Calais.' 
Whether  a  new  nomination  was  occasioned  by  his  death  or  resignation  is 
uncertain,  but  we  find 

Nicholas  de  Ottirburn  styled  Vicar  of  Edinburgh,  on  the  8th  of 
June  1455,*  in  the  safe-conduct  granted  to  George  Bishop  of  Brechin,  Wil- 
liam Earl  of  Orkney,  and  others.  He  also  was  a  person  much  employed  in 
public  affairs,  and  had  completed  his  studies  at  St.  Andrews,  being  one  of 
the  Determinants  in  1419,  and  a  Licentiate  either  in  1420  or  1421.  In  an

in  his  official  capacity  on  the  26th  of  August  1447,  in  which  he  is  designated

the  Glasgow  Chartulary.^  His  nephew,  John  de  Otterburn,  Provost  of  the

William  Forbes,  Canon  of  Aberdeen,  was  the  next  incumbent  as 
Vicar  of  St.  Giles,  and  his  name  appears  in  a  deed  of  the  year  14G4. 
During  his  time  the  parish  church,  in  its  decorated  style  of  architecture, 
had  assumed  its  enlarged  and  completed  form.  A  large  number  of  altars, 
more  or  less  richly  endowed,  had  been  founded  within  distinct  chapels, 
by  the  piety  and  munificence  of  persons  of  various  ranks;  not  less  than 
thirty  separate  altars  being  indicated  in  the  following  charters  ;  and  the 
enlargement  of  the  fabric  affords  a  satisfactory  proof  of  a  desire  to  adapt  the 
church  to  the  religious  wants  of  the  increasing  population.  Kinf  James 
the  Third,  at  the  request  of  the  magistrates  and  community  of  Edin- 
burgh, in  a  charter  under  the  Great  Seal,  dated  the  28th  of  October 
1466,  granted  his  consent  for  the  erection  of  St.  Giles's  Church  into  a  Col- 
legiate institution  ;  *  but  a  delay  of  some  years  would  seem  to  have  occurred 
in  carrying  this  intention  into  effect.  The  death,  a  few  months  previously, 
of  James  Kennedy,  Bishop  of  St.  Andrews,  who  had  held  the  Commenda- 
tory of  Scone,  and  is  supposed  to  have  been  a  benefactor  to  the  Church  of 
St.  Giles,  may  have  contributed  to  this  delay.  The  charters  of  erection  and 
confirmation  are  not  preserved  ;  but  Patrick  Graham,  his  successor,  who, 
during  his  visit  to  Rome,  had  obtained  the  erection  of  the  See  of  St.  Andrews 
into  an  Archbishopric,  must  have  confirmed  the  Royal  charter  and  procured 
the  Papal  consent  to  the  erection  of  St.  Giles  into  a  Collegiate  Church,  before 
he  fell  under  the  King's  displeasure,  and  ended  his  days  in  captivity.  In  char- 
ters dated  the  25th  of  February  1467-8,  20th  of  September  1470,  and  6th  of 
July  1471,  the  church  still  continued  to  be  designated  Ecclesia  parochialis 
Beati  ^gidii.     But  in  a  charter  which  was  discovered  after  the  printino-  of

new  establishment.  To  the  King  was  reserved  the  nomination  of  the  Dean 
or  Provost,  who  was  to  enjoy  the  tithes  and  other  revenues  of  St.  Giles's 
Church,  with  the  adjacent  manse  ;  and  the  Provost  had  the  right  of  choosing 
a  Curate,  who  was  to  have  a  yearly  allowance  of  25  marks,  with  a  house 
adjoining. 

It  might  be  supposed  from  the  distinct  and  explicit  statements  given

his  information  from  some  later  document  in  which  the  particular  revenues 
assigned  to  each  of  the  priests  were  recapitulated ;  but  his  statement  is  so 
minute  and  apparently  accurate,  that  it  may  be  transferred  to  these  pages.

"  This  Collegiate  foundation  consisted  of  a  provost,  curate,  sixteen  prebendaries,  a

"  The  Provost,  for  his  maintenance  and  support  of  his  dignity,  was  to  receive  the 
fruits,  rents,  and  profits,  together  with  the  adjacent  manse,  or  parsonage-house,  and 
glebe  belonging  to  the  church,  with  the  right  of  chusing  a  Curate,  to  whom  he  was  to 
allow  the  sum  of  twenty-five  marks  yearly,  with  a  house  near  the  church,  to  dwell  in.

in  the  absence  of  the  two  senior  prebendaries,  and  not  to  be  removed  but  by  an  act  of 
the  Provost  and  Chapter.

Mr.  William  Forbes,  Perpetual  Vicar,  was  advanced  to  the  Provostship 
of  the  newly  erected  Collegiate  Church.  He  was  educated  at  St.  Andrews,

tiates In  1451  iu  that  University.  In  the  year  1464,  he  was  elected  Rector.^ 
After  his  appointment  as  Provost  of  St.  Giles,  Forbes  obtained  a  charter 
under  the  Great  Seal,  dated  2d  of  October  1478,"  confirming  to  him  for  life 
an  annual  pension  or  stipend  of  220  marks,  which  had  been  granted  by  the

the  town's  charters,  &c.,  there  is  entered, — "  Item,  ane  discharge  granted 
be  Mr.  William  Forbess,  Provost  of  the  Colledge  Kirk  of  St.  Geill,  wherby

Gawin  Douglas,  third  son  of  Archibald,  fifth  Earl  of  Angus,  by 
Elizabeth,  daughter  of  Robert  Lord  Boyd,  Lord  High  Chamberlain  of  Scot- 
land, was  the  next  Provost  of  St.  Giles.  He  was  born  about  the  year  1474, 
and  was  educated  for  the  Church.  In  the  registers  of  the  University  of  St. 
Andrews,  his  name  occurs  in  the  lists  of  Incorporati  in  1489,  of  the  Determi- 
nantes  in  1492,  and  of  the  Licentiati,  or  Masters  of  Arts,  in  1494.^  ^Vith  his 
high  family  connexions,  it  was  not  likely  that  Douglas  would  fail  in  securing 
preferment.  We  accordingly  find  that  in  149(3,  he  had  a  grant  of  the  teinds 
of  Monj-musk  in  Aberdeenshire.'  Two  years  later  he  obtained  from  the 
Bang  a  presentation  to  the  parsonage  of  Glenquhom  when  it  should  become 
vacant  by  the  resignation  of  Sir  Alexander  Symson.*  He  also  became  Par- 
son of  Lyntoun,  and  Eector  of  Hawch  now  known  as  Prestonkirk,  in  East 
Lothian  ;  but  the  dates  are  uncertain.  As  the  latter  preferment  has  fre- 
quently been  mistaken,  a  few  explanatory  words  may  be  added.  Sir  John 
Ireland  was  parson  of  Halch  in  June  1493,  when  a  suit  was  heard  in  Parlia- 
ment regarding  his  right  of  pasturage  on  the  moor  of  Preston.^     In    his

Alexander  Myln  styles  him  Rector  de  Hauche.  By  mistaking  the  name,

In  his  allegorical  poem,  T]ie  Palice  of  Honour,  written  in  the  year 
1501,  Douglas  concludes  with  a  poetical  address  to  King  James  the  Fourth, 
in  which,  with  what  may  be  called  false  modesty,  he  refers  to  his  own  "  vul- 
gair  ignorance,"  and  says, 

Ressave  this  roustie  rurall  reljaldrie, 
Laikand  cunning,  fra  thy  pure  leige  unlaird. 

It  may  at  least  be  conjectured  that  when  the  Provostship  of  the  church  be- 
came vacant,  this'  performance  had  some  effect  in  inducing  the  King  to  bring 
the  author  from  his  rural  occupations,  and  to  advance  him  to  a  place  of  con- 
siderable dignity  and  emolument.  The  precise  date  of  his  appointment  is 
uncertain,  but  we  find  from  the  Treasurer's  Accounts,  that  the  sum  of  nine 
shillings  was  paid  on  the  11th  of  March  1502-3,  "  to  Sir  John  Ireland, 
Vicar  of  Perth,  for  writing  off  the  citations  and  letters  on  Maister  Gawin 
Douglas,  Prowest  of  Sanct  Gelis  Kirk."^  No  deeds  signed  by  him  as

Lords  of  Council,  connected  with  his  own  advancement  when  nominated  to

"  Maister  Gawine  Douglas,  Postulate  of  Aberbrothok,  and  shew,  how  he  was 
a  man  of  forty  years  of  age,  and  how  he  had  passit  his  time  in  Scotland, 
England,  France,  and  Rome,  without  defamation  or  any  reprief  to  his 
honesty,  as  was  known  to  divers  of  my  Lordis  thare  present,"'  &c.  His 
translation  of  the  iEneid  of  Virgil  into  Scottish  verse,  the  work  which  has 
conferred  so  much  lustre  on  his  name,  was  the  labour  of  eighteen  months, 
and  was  completed,  he  informs  us,  on  the  22d  of  July  1513,  or  seven  weeks 
before  the  fatal  battle  of  Floddon.  He  further  states  that  it  was  undertaken 
at  the  request  of  his  cousin,  Henry  Lord  Sinclair,^  whom  he  characterizes  as 
"Father  of  books,  protector  of  sciences  and  lare  (or  learning)  ;"  and  his 
epistle,  directed  to  this  noble  patron,  begins, 

My  Lord,  to  your  nobilite  in  effect, 
To  quham  this  wark  I  have  above  direct, 
Gawane,  your  cousing,  Provest  of  Sanct  Geill, 
Grating  in  God,  ay  lasting  in  gud  Iieill.

Council  Records  of  Edinburgh,  that  he  was  admitted  a  freeman  of  the  city.

During  the  reign  of  James  the  Fourth,  various  burgesses  of  Edinburgh 
became  liberal  benefactors  to  the  Church  of  St.  Giles,  chiefly  for  the  endow- 
ment of  altars.  Among  these  may  be  mentioned,  besides  William  Forbes 
first  Provost  of  the  Collegiate  Church,  Walter  Bertram,  Provost  of  Edin- 
burgh in  1481,  and  again  in  1494  ;  Walter  Chepman  of  Ewerland,  our 
Scottish  Caxton  ;  Elchard  Hopper  ;  Sir  Alexander  Lauder,  also  Provost  of 
the  city  for  several  years  from  1501  to  1511  ;  Eichard  Lawson  of  Hieriggs, 
and  Janet  Elphinstone,  his  spouse  ;  Andrew  Mowbray,  apparently  connected 
with  the  Mowbrays  of  Barnbougle  ;  Archibald  Napier  of  Edinkellie  and 
Merchiston  ;  Alexander  Rynde,  and  Robert  Vaus  ;  while  the  incorporated 
trades  seem  to  have  vied  with  each  other  for  the  support  and  decoration  of 
the  altars  of  their  patron  saints.  Among  the  persons  we  have  named, 
Chepman  is  particularly  worthy  of  notice.  He  had  been  employed  at  the 
Court  of  Holyrood  as  clerk  (clericus),  and  also  as  a  merchant,  from  the 
early  part  of  the  King's  reign.  In  the  year  1507  he  obtained  letters  of 
exclusive   privilege  for  the  establishment  of  a  printing   preas.^     He   had

a  charter  under  the  Great  Seal,  dated  the  21st  of  August  1513  ;' 
endowing  a  secular  priest  to  officiate  continually  at  the  Altar  of  St.  John 
the  Evangelist,  in  the  chapel  which  he  had  recently  founded  (in  capella 
ipsius  per  me  noviter  fundata)  in  the  south  part  of  the  Church  of  St.  Giles, 
for  the  welfare  of  the  souls  of  the  King,  the  Queen,  and  their  offspring,  as 
well  as  for  himself  and  his  relations.  Within  four  weeks  of  the  date  of  this 
charter,  James  the  Fourth  met  his  untimely  fate  at  the  field  of  Floddon. 
After  the  lapse  of  nearly  fifteen  years,  Chepman  gave  a  fresh  proof  of  his 
attachment  to  the  memory  of  his  royal  master,  having  in  1528,  when  far  ad- 
vanced in  years,  endowed  another  chaplainry  at  the  Altar  of  Jesus  Crucified, 
within  the  mortuary  chapel  of  the  Holy  Cross  situated  in  the  lower  part  of 
the  cemetery  of  St.  Giles.^  By  this  foundation,  prayers  were  appointed  spe- 
cially to  be  offered  for  the  souls  of  the  King,  the  Nobles,  and  others  slain  at 
Ftoddon  ;  for  the  souls  of  his  present  as  well  as  former  spouse  ;  and  for  the 
souls  of  all  the  faithful  of  both  sexes,  buried  or  to  be  buried  within  the  col- 
legiate church  or  in  the  adjoining  cemetery.  The  religious  services  thus 
prescribed  ceased  during  the  second  generation,  and  the  mortuary  chapel 
was  demolished  ;'  but  the  charter  itself  has  been  preserved,  with  Chepman's

RoBERT  Crichton,  who  appears  to  have  been  the  immediate  successor 
of  Bishop  Douglas  as  Provost  of  St.  Giles,  must  have  been  born  towards 
the  close  of  the  fifteenth  century.  He  was  a  younger  son  of  Sir  Patrick 
Crichton  of  Cranstoun  Riddell,  and  nephew  of  George  Crichton  of  Nauch- 
ton,  who  was  Abbot  of  Holyrood  (1516-1526)  and  Bishop  of  Dunkeld 
(1527-1544),  and  through  whom  he  evidently  obtained,  at  an  early  period 
of  life,  his  preferment  in  the  Church.  He  was  educated  at  St.  Andrews, 
where  he  was  incorporated  in  the  year  1512.  To  his  name,  Eobertus 
Crichton,  there  is  added,  "  Propositus  Edinburgi,"  by  some  later  hand. 
In  the  list  of  Determinants  or  Bachelors  of  Arts,  in  Pcedagogio,  primus 
actus,  in  the  year  1514,  Robertus  Crichton  is  marked  dives,  a  distinc- 
tion from  the  paitperes  or  poor  students  who  paid  no  fees  ;  and  on  the 
23d  May  1516,  he  was  admitted  a  Licentiate.  Before  he  had  taken  his 
Masters'  degree,  he  was  elected  Parish  Clerk  of  the  Aisle  and  Altar  of 
Holyrood,  vacant  by  the  decease  of  Patrick  Bellenden.'  The  date  of  his 
actual  preferment  to  St.  Giles's  Church  is  uncertain.  In  the  Provost's 
absence,  the  Curate  or  first  Prebendary  acted  as  President,  "  for  the  guid 
rewle  to  be  had  in  their  College  of  Sanct  Gele."^  On  the  institution  of 
a  Prebend,  12th  of  June  1521,  Magister  Robertus  Crichton  is  styled  "  Pre- 
positus  Ecclesia?  coUegiatse  Beati  Egidii  de  Edinburgh,"  but  it  is  added, 
he  was  at  that  time   absent,    "  nunc   causa   studii   in   remotis  agentis."'

His  resort  abroad,  at  a  later  period  at  least,  was  rather  to  insure  his  own 
preferment,  than  to  prosecute  his  studies.  His  uncle,  George  Crichton, 
Bishop  of  Dunkeld,  died  in  1543-4,  and  is  said  to  have  made  a  resignation 
of  the  See  in  Robert's  favour,  who  proceeded  to  Rome  for  the  purpose  of 
urging  his  suit.  But  the  interest  of  the  Governor  secured  the  appointment 
for  his  natural  brother,  John  Hamilton,  Abbot  of  Paisley,  early  in  1545; 
and  proceedings  by  the  Scottish  Parliament  were  instituted  in  August  154(3, 
against  Mr.  Robert  Crichton,  Provost  of  Sanct  Gells  Kirk,  for  opposing  the 
presentation  of  John  Abbot  of  Paisley  to  the  vacant  See  of  Dunkeld,  "  as 
prejudicial  to  our  Soverane  Ladyis  interest;"^  and  in  a  letter  from  Patrick 
Liddale,  dated  at  Rome,  17th  October  1546,  it  is  stated  that  "  Bonar 
(Bishop  of  London)  laborit  to  got  command  fra  the  Pape  to  cause  the  buUes 
of  Dunkeld  be  sped  in  favour  of  the  Provost  of  St.  Gelis  Kyrk  ;  because  he 
could  nocht  cum  speed  thereof,  he  stopit  [David  Panter,  Bishop  of]  Ross, 
be  sinisteris  informationis."'  A  vacancy  having  occurred  at  St.  Andrews, 
in  May  1546,  Hamilton  after  a  protracted  interval  of  three  years,  was  pro- 
moted to  that  See,  and  Crichton  became  his  successor  as  Bishop  of  Dun- 
keld.^ On  the  17th  March  1549-50,  the  Chapter  of  Dunkeld  held  a  meeting 
sede  vacante,  but  in  the  course  of  that  year  he  was  consecrated  Bishop.  He 
however  seems  still  to  have  retained  the  Provostry  of  St.  Giles,  as  he  is  so 
designated  in  charters  dated  in  1551,  and  the  two  following  years.*  But  on 
these  occasions,  Lawrence  Tod,  as  deputy,  acted  in  his  place,  being  styled 
Vicar,  and  President  of  the  Church  of  St.  Giles.'

certain  teinds  of  kirklands  assigned  to  their  use,  it  is  stated  that  a  lease  for 
nineteen  years  had  been  granted  by  them  to  Laurence  Lord  Oliphant  in 
June  1551.  Notwithstanding  the  odium  attached  to  the  Reformers,  there 
can  be  no  doubt  that  great  indulgence  was  shown  to  the  Popish  incum- 
bents of  Church  livings  in  allowing  them  a  certain  proportion  of  the 
revenues  during  their  lives,  except  in  cases  of  such  as  had  incurred  the 
penalties  of  forfeiture  for  civil  crimes.  In  the  suit  referred  to,  it  was  ad- 
judged that  the  right  to  the  annualrents  belonged  to  the  said  Provost  and 
Prebendaries,  as  the  lawful  superiors  for  the  time  being.  Chisholme 
also  continued  in  possession  of  the  Provost's  house  and  glebe,  and  the  Pre- 
bendaries theirs  in  like  manner  ;  so  that  when  John  Knox  became  mini- 
ster of  Edinburgh,  in  15(j0,  the  Magistrates  and  Council  were  under  the 
necessity  of  providing  him  accommodation,  in  the  dwelUng-house  at  the 
Netherbow  which  still  retains  his  name,  and  which  has  recently  undergone 
the  process  of  restoration.  Chisholme  probably  belonged  to  the  Cromlix 
family,  but  no  certain  information  regarding  his  history  has  been  discovered. 
A  fac-simile  of  his  signature  may  be  added,  as  it  occurs  in  the  lease  of  his 
dwelling-house,  which  he  granted  to  David  Lord  Drummond,  and  Lilias 
Ruthven,  his  second  wife,  at  Stobhall,  2d  of  July  1566,  for  the  annualrent 
of  five  marks,  reserving  to  himself  or  the  provost  and  curate  of  the  church 
a  bed-chamber  within  the  said  dwelling-house,  when  he  should  happen  to 
be  resident.^

•  Charter,  No.  152,  p.  267. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  xli 

fer,  among  "  Certane  auld  Statutis  collcctit  furth  of  tlie  revin  (torn)  auld 
bukis  of  the  Toun  of  Edinburgh,"  several  entries  occur,  imposing  fines  for 
breaking  the  Statutes,  one-half  or  two-thirds  of  such  fines  being  appro- 
priated to  "  the  Kirk  wark  of  St.  Giles."  Some  of  these  statutes  were  ap- 
plicable to  the  freighting  of  vessels  to  Flanders,  others  to  the  grinding  of  meal 
at  the  common  mills,  and  the  buying  and  selling  wines  at  fixed  prices.  The 
freemen  of  the  various  crafts,  upon  their  admission,  were  liable  to  a  tax,  which 
was  appropriated  to  the  same  purpose.  It  is  not  less  worthy  of  notice  that 
when  King  James  the  Third,  in  1482,  granted  the  office  of  sheriffs  of  the 
borough  of  Edinburgh  to  the  Provost,  Bailies,  Council,  and  Community,  he 
bound  them  to  apply  a  portion  of  the  profits  accruing  from  the  otfice  to  the 
celebration  of  the  services  in  St.  Giles.^  Other  penalties  applied  to  "  the 
Kirk  wark"  are  more  singular.  On  the  7th  of  November  1485,  it  was 
enacted  that  none  of  the  common  rents  be  set  to  "  ony  man  of  Leith  ; "  and 
that  no  one  shall  have  "  in  his  service  ony  persoun  dwelland  in  Leith,"  under 
the  penalty  of  £10  to  the  Kirk  wark,  and  the  loss  of  his  freedom  for  a 
year  and  a  day."  In  1520,  William  Forsyth  was  fined  £5  •'  for  sellino-  of 
his  wyne  opinlie  in  the  tavernis  of  Leith."  In  1522,  two  persons  were  to 
have  their  effects  distrained  by  the  town's  officers  for  "  selling  of  their  wj'ne 
for  xiid.  the  pynt,"  the  half  of  the  sum  to  be  applied  to  Sanct  Gelis  wark,  the 
other  half  to  St.  Anthon's  altar.  In  August  1498,  as  a  security  for  prevent- 
ing the  frequent  disturbances  in  the  streets  of  Edinburgh,  which  usually  ended 
in  bloodshed  and  murder,  both  merchants  and  craftsmen  were  enjoined  to 
have  in  their  booths  "defensabill  geir,  sikas  jak,  sellet,  burgandynis,  o-luifis 
of  plait,  and  ane  hand-ax  or  sword ; "  and  to  be  in  readiness,  when  the  alarm 
was  given,  to  meet  the  provost,  bailies,  and  quartermasters,  for  repressing 
such  tumults,  under  the  penalty  of  £20  "  to  the  Kirk  wark  ; "  and  the  person 
who  was  not  of  substance  to  pay  this  fine,  was  "  to  be  set  on  the  goif,  and  thair 
haldin  thi-ee  dayis,  and  the  caus  of  his  goving  descrivit  in  writt  besyde  him,

harsh  penalty  incurred  by  poverty.  On  the  4th  of  January  1511-12,  John 
Rynde,  prebendary  of  Railston,  with  the  consent  of  the  provost,  bailies,  &c., 
gave  a  lease  of  the  quarry  of  Railston,  or  Ravelston,  for  the  yearly  sum  of 
three  pounds  and  a  cow's  grass,  the  tenant  binding  himself  to  furnish  stones 
for  the  Kirk  wark,  and  to  the  neighbours  of  the  town,  at  the  old  prices.  This 
quarry,  about  a  mile  to  the  north-west  of  Edinburgh,  is  supposed  to  have 
formed  part  of  the  extensive  freestone  quarries  of  Ravelston  on  Corstorphine 
hill,  and  to  have  furnished  the  stones  with  which  the  public  buildings  in  the 
city  continued  to  be  erected,  including  the  Parliament  House  and  Heriot's 
Hospital.'  In  March  1541-2,  Sir  Richard  Lawsoun,  prebendary,  set  in  feu  to 
Alexander  Scott,  son  of  Walter  Scott,  the  lands  of  Grottell,  also  in  the  vici- 
nity of  Edinburgh,  for  three  marks  yearly.  In  July  1540,  James  Prestoun 
conveyed  to  the  town  his  house  and  land  at  the  east  entry  of  their  College 
kirk  of  St.  Geill ;  and  at  the  same  time  the  occupiers  of  the  booths  pertain- 
ing to  the  town  were  made  liable  for  the  feu-duties  of  their  booths  for  the 
period  of  five  years,  "  to  the  eflFect  that  with  the  samyn  James  Person's 
[Prestoun's]  land  at  the  east  end  of  the  kirk  may  be  bought,  and  make  an 
entres  to  the  kirk  for  the  honour  of  God  and  policie  of  the  gude  town." 
In  October  1543,  John  AVatsoun,  "glassinwricht,"  for  the  annual  sum  of  six 
marks,  undertook,  during  his  lifetime,  to  uphold  the  whole  glass  and  win- 
dows of  the  kirk,  and  to  furnish  glass,  lead,  and  tin  ;  the  Dean  of  Guild 
engaging  to  provide  iron,  scaffolding,  and  ladders,  when  such  were  required. 
In  January  1552-3,  James  Lauder,  prebendary  of  their  choir,  obtained  a 
licence  "  to  pas  furth  of  the  realme  to  the  partes  of  England  and  France,  thair 
to  remane  for  the  space  of  ane  yeir  nixt  efter  the  dait  heirof,  to  the  effect 
that  he  may  have  and  get  better  erudition  in  Musik  and  Playing  nor  he  hes  ; 
providing  always  that  the  said  James  cans  an  chaiplane  to  keip  his  founda- 
tioun  of  Sanct  Katharynis  alter  be  ane  preist  quhill  the  said  yeir  be  done." 
In  July  1554,  Andro  Mansioun  "  wrycht  to  the  bigging  of  the  stallis  of  the 
queir,  having  done  his  uter  devoir  and  diligence  therein,"  the  provost, 
bailies,  and  counsale,  and  deacons  of  crafts,  were  so  much  satisfied  with  the 

'  New  Statistical  Account,  Edinburgh,  Parish  of  Corstorphine,  p.  207. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  xliii 

manner  of  completing  his  task,  that  they  awarded  him  an  annual  pension  of 
ten  marks  for  a  period  of  ten  years.  On  the  12th  of  April  1559,  Mansioun 
of  his  own  free  will  resigned  this  pension  which  he  had  "  in  reward  of 
his  labours  upon  the  stallis  of  thequeir."  Three  months  later,  it  was  found 
necessary  for  the  safe  custody  of  the  stalls  to  have  them  removed  to  the 
Tolbooth.  But  without  dwelling  on  such  matters,  however  curious  the 
detail  may  be,  it  is  of  more  importance  to  allude  to  the  changes  in  which 
St.  Giles's  Church  was  involved  by  the  great  movement  known  as  The 
Reformation. 

The  people  of  Scotland  had,  for  nearly  thirty  years,  been  gradually 
preparing  for  such  a  momentous  event,  and  for  extirpating  from  the  land  all 
objects  of  idolatry.  The  frequent  spectacle  of  persons  committed  to  the 
flames  on  the  Castle  Hill  of  Edinburgh,  and  in  other  places,  on  the  charge 
of  heresy,  instead  of  repressing,  only  excited  the  sympathy  and  prompted 
the  inquiries  of  the  spectators.  In  regard  to  Edinburgh,  it  had  long  been 
customary  on  the  1st  of  September  to  celebrate  the  anniversary  of  the  tute- 
lar saint,  by  a  public  procession  through  the  streets ;  and  a  figure  of  St. 
Giles  carved  in  wood,  the  size  of  life,  and  mounted  on  priests'  shoulders, 
had  hitherto  formed  a  conspicuous  object.  In  the  year  1558,  notwithstand- 
ing the  prevalence  of  the  Reformed  opinions  among  the  citizens,  it  was 
resolved  to  celebrate  this  festival  with  more  than  ordinary  solemnity,  but 
which.  In  less  troublous  times,  might  have  assumed  the  character  of  an  auto 
da  fe  ;  and  several  heretics,  it  is  said,  were  reserved  for  this  occasion,  to 
bear  faggots  and  perform  public  penance,  while  the  Queen-Regent  was  to 
countenance  the  procession  with  her  presence.  But  before  the  anniversary 
arrived,  Knox  states  that  "  the  images  were  stollen  away  in  all  parts  of  the 
country ;  and  in  Edinburgh  was  tliat  great  idolle  called  Sajict  Gile,  first 
drowned  in  the  North  Loch,  and  after  burnt,  which,"  he  adds,  "raised  no 
small  trouble  at  the  time."  This  trouble  refers  to  an  injunction  of  the 
Archbishop  of  St.  Andrews  either  to  recover  the  old  Sanct  Geill,  or  to 
replace  this  "great  idoll"  with  another,  under  the  penalty  of  his  great 
cursing.     The  magistrates  of  the  city  thought  such  a  charge  to  be  unjust.

and  desired  that  prelate  to  find  a  warrant  in  Scripture  for  setting  up  images  ; 
and  "  because  they  obeyed  him  not,  he  caused  his  curate,  Tod,^  to  curse 
them  as  black  as  coal ;  from  the  which  they  appealed  to  his  unholy  father 
the  Pope.""  It  would  occupy  too  much  space  to  refer  further  to  this  Appel- 
lation ;  but  matters  of  greater  importance  intervening,  "this  afi'air  passed  in

the  procession.

&c.  .  .  .  The  minister  of  God's  word,  John  Knox,  tlie  same  dny  that  the  Con- 
gregation came  to  Edinburgh,  made  a  sermon  in  St.  Giles's  Church,  and  the 
next  day  in  the  Abbay,  soe  that  the  dumbe  idolls,  and  all  darkness  being 
taken  away,  the  clear  light-shining  of  God's  word  was  truely  preached." ' 
A  few  days  later,  "the  Congregation  of  Edinburgh  elected  and  chose 
John  Knox,  publicly  in  the  Tolbooth  of  Edinburgh,  for  their  Minister 
the  7th  of  July  1559."  In  the  previous  month,  the  Council  had  given  direc- 
tions for  the  safe  custody  of  the  Jewells,  vestments,  ornaments,  and  silver 
work  of  the  High  Altar.  On  the  12th  of  July,  the  stalls  of  the  queir  or 
choir,  were  directed  to  be  removed  to  the  Nether  Tolbooth  for  their  pre- 
servation ;  and  on  the  29th,  a  meeting  took  place  between  the  Queen's  Com- 
missioners and  a  deputation  from  the  Lords  of  the  Congregation,  at  which 
the  latter  asserted  their  rights  to  "  the  Hie  Kirk  of  this  Town,  callit  Sanct 
Geillis  Kirk." ' 

In  November  1559,  the  affairs  of  the  Congregation  were  so  changed, 
that  they  departed  hastily  from  Edinburgh,  and  the  French  auxiliary  troops 
having  taken  possession  of  the  city,  the  Romish  worship  was  restored, 
and  St.  Giles's  Church  was  consecrated  anew  by  the  Bishop  of  Amiens.^ 
But  this  state  of  things  was  not  of  long  continuance.  In  the  month  of 
March  following,  Archibald  Douglas  of  Kilspindie,  Provost,  and  the  Council 
ordained  the  Dean  of  Guild  "  to  reparrel  the  Kirk,  to  lay  the  throuchis 
(grave-stones)  thairof  of  new,  and  sparge  (whitewash)  the  same,  and  to  mend 
the  windows,  and  to  make  convenient  seats  in  the  church.'"^  In  the  pre- 
vious month,  the  annual  rents  due  to  certain  prebendaries  were  ordered  to 
be  paid  ;  but  discharged  any  future  payments  to  others  of  their  number 
"because  they  have  not  awaited  upon  the  divine  service.""  In  the  Dean 
of  Guild's  disbursements,  in  May  or  June  1560,  we  have  this  entry  :  "  Item, 
to  ten  warkmen  quha  wrocht  be  the  space  of  nyne  dayis,  for  takin  doun  of 
the  haill  Altaris  of  the  Kirk,  of  the  Rude  loft,  (and)  for  berino-  of  the  red

The  great  religious  question  having  been  determined  in  August  1560, 
when  the  Scottish  Parliament  sanctioned  the  Presbyterian  forms  of  disci- 
pline and  church  government,  "  all  claim  and  title  to  altars  and  revenues  in 
the  kirk  "  were  discharged,  and  regulations  prescribed  for  the  accommoda- 
tion of  the  inhabitants.  St.  Giles's  Church  having  thus  been  stripped  of  its 
sculptured  images  and  decorations,  and  the  numerous  altars  removed,  a  por- 
tion of  it  continued  to  be  used  for  public  worship  by  the  community,  John 
Knox  being  sole  minister  of  Edinburgh,  with  the  assistance  of  a  reader. 

In  February  1560-1,  the  Council  ordered  the  Dean  of  Guild,  with  all 
diligence,  to  complete  the  stone  gable  at  the  west  end  of  Sanct  Gelis  Kirk, 
and  other  necessary  work  within  the  said  kirk.  This  may  probably  account 
for  the  disappearance  of  any  traces  of  the  great  western  door.  In  March 
1568,  he  was  directed  "  to  belt  and  mend  the  great  window  of  the  east  gable 
of  the  kirk,  and  the  window  in  Sanct  Thomas  Aisle;"  "  the  great  wyndois 
of  Sanct  Gelis  Kirk,  having  been  blawin  down,  and  the  maist  part  of  the 
rufe  tyrvit  (uncovered)  be  the  last  greit  wynd,  swa  that  the  pepill  sail 
nocht  convene  thairintill  at  preching  and  prayer." 

But  the  Church  of  St.  Giles  suffered  not  only  from  such  accidents,  as 
well  as  from  the  over-zeal  of  the  early  reformers,  but  also  from  the  effects 
of  civil  contention,  when  Sir  William  Kirkaldy  of  Grange  and  Queen  Marj^'s 
adherents  retained  possession  of  the  Castle.  On  the  28th  of  March  15?!, 
Kirkaldy  took  forcible  possession  of  St.  Giles's  Church,  and  placed  some  of 
his  men  in  the  steeple  to  keep  the  citizens  in  awe.  On  the  4th  of  June,  "  the 
men  of  weir  in  the  steipill  slappit  all  the  pendis  of  the  kirk  for  keeping  thairof 
aganis  my  Lord  Regent  ;"  and  on  the  20th,  "  there  was  placed  in  the  steiple 
of  Edinburgh  thre  peices  of  brasin  ordinance,  with  victuallis  and  uthers  ne- 
cessaris  for  defending  of  the  samyne."  Calderwood  repeats  the  same  state- 
ment, that  the  rebels  of  the  Castle  began,  on  the  2d  of  May  1571,  to  fortify 
the  town,  and,  on  the  same  day,  "  to  make  holes  in  the  vaute  of  the  Great 


1  HISTORICAL  NOTICES  OF 

Kirk  of  Edinburgh,  which  they  made  like  a  riddell,  to  shoot  thorough  at 
suche  as  they  pleased  within  the  kirk,  or  at  such  as  would  prease  to  breake 
doun  the  pillers."  ^  This  state  of  affairs  was  partly  terminated  on  the  27th 
of  July  1572,  when  "the  haill  artillery  in  Edinburgh,  about  the  walls,  on 
the  steipill-head  of  Sanct  Geill,  and  Kirk  of  Field,  war  tane  to  the  Castle  of 
Edinburgh."  " 

Towards  the  closing  period  of  the  Reformer's  life,  on  returning  to  Edin- 
burgh on  the  last  day  of  August  1572,  he  preached  "  in  the  Great  Kirk  :  but 
because  his  voice  was  become  weaker,  he  desired  another  place  to  teache  in, 
if  it  were  but  to  an  hundreth  persons  ;  which  was  granted."  ^  For  this  pur- 
pose a  portion  of  the  church  was  enclosed  as  a  separate  place  of  worship.  He 
died  on  the  24th  of  the  ensuing  November,  and  was  interred  in  the  common 
burying-ground  at  the  south  side  of  St.  Giles's  Church,  in  the  presence  of 
the  Regent  Earl  of  Morton,  the  rest  of  the  nobilit}',  and  a  great  concourse  of 
people.  Like  his  great  coadjutor  Calvin,  at  Geneva,  no  stone  or  memorial 
appears  to  have  been  erected  to  mark  the  place  of  his  interment ;  but  there 
is  reason  to  believe  it  was  nearly  in  a  line  with  the  entrance  to  the  south 
transept,  a  little  to  the  west  of  the  base  of  Charles  the  Second's  equestrian 
statue,  in  the  Parliament  Close.  In  such  a  site  a  statue  of  the  great  Refor- 
mer would  have  been  much  more  appropriate.  Three  years  previously,  the 
Regent  Earl  of  Murray,  amidst  general  lamentations  at  his  untimely  fate, 
was  buried  within  the  church,  and  a  monument  was  erected  to  his  memory 
at  the  public  expense.  In  restoring  the  church,  it  might  have  been  thought 
that  such  a  monument  would  have  escaped  any  sacrilegious  hand  ;  but  to 
the  disgrace  of  our  civic  authorities,  it  was  allowed  to  be  demolished,  and 
the  brass  tablet,  containing  engraved  figures  of  Justice  and  Faith,  with  an 
inscription  written  by  Buchanan,  was  removed.*  The  monument  itself  can- 
not now  be  replaced,  but  it  may  be  hoped  that  this  monumental  brass,  one 
of  the  few  existing  specimens  in  Scotland,  will  yet,  as  it  unquestionably 
ought,  be  replaced  in  the  wall  of  the  south  transept.

The  mortuary  chapel  connected  with  the  cemetery  already  alluded  to, 
was  demolished  in  the  year  1561/  In  the  following  year"  Queen  Mary 
had  conveyed,  by  a  grant,  the  grounds  of  the  Greyfriars  to  the  Town  of 
Edinburgh,  for  the  purpose  of  a  burial-place  ;  the  Magistrates,  in  their 
supplication,  having  solicited  that  "  Youre  Hieness  will  gif  to  ws  the  yairdis 
of  the  Grayfrieris  and  situatioun  thairof,  being  sumquhat  distant  from  oure 
Toune,  to  mak  ane  buriale  place  of,  to  burie  and  eird  the  personis  deceis- 
sand  theirin,  sua  that  thairthrow  the  air  within  oure  said  toune  may  be  the 
mair  pure  and  clene."  On  the  same  day,  the  Council  ordained  "  Edward 
alias  Sir  Edward  Hendersoun  to  tak  cure  and  charge  over  the  warkis  of  the 
toune  at  St.  Geillis  kirkyaird,  the  Blak,  and  Gray  Frieris  ;  and  ordainis 
to  gyve  him  2  shillings  on  the  day  for  his  labouris,  induring  thair  willis." 
The  erection  of  the  Parliament  House  in  1631  was  obviously  the  means  of 
obliterating  the  public  burying-ground  round  the  church  ;  but  the  mass  of 
human  bones  found  in  its  immediate  proximity  during  the  process  of  reno- 
vation bore  ample  testimony  of  its  previous  existence.  "  By  ray  own  obser- 
vation," says  John  Weever,  in  his  Ancient  Funeral  Monuments,  first  pub- 
lished in  1631,  "m  the  famous  maiden  city  of  Edinburgh,  and  in  the  parish 
churches  of  other  towns,  the  sepidchres  of  the  dead  are  shamefully  abused, 
or  QUiTE  TAKEN  AWAY  ;  yea,  and  the  churches  themselves,  with  religious 
houses  and  other  holy  places,  violated,  demolished,  or  defaced."  ^
