It  had  long  been  the  practice  to  stipulate  the  repayment  of  certain  sums 
for  the  redemption  of  lands,  upon  the  high  altar  of  the  principal  church  of 
the  parish,  between  the  rising  and  setting  of  the  sun.  Many  instances 
of  this  practice  might  be  quoted  from  old  deeds  ;  but  it  may  be  suflicient 
to  refer  to  two,  in  which  the  Church  of  St.  Giles  is  specially  mentioned  in 
the  years  1452^  and  1543.^  After  the  altars  had  been  destroyed,  the  same 
custom  of  discharging  any  mutual  contracts  within  the  walls  of  the  church 
still  continued.  Even  so  late  as  the  year  1715,  Sir  Walter  Scott  mentions 
a  deed  by  Lord  Sinclair,  "setting  forth,  that  although  the  fee  of  the 
estate  of  Ravenscraig  was  settled  upon  his  son  John,  Master  of  Sinclair, 
yet  that  the  said  fee  was  redeemable  upon  the  grantor  making  pay- 
ment of  a  rose  noble,  or  four  pounds  Scots  money,  within  St.  Geill's 
Church  in  Edinburgh,  at  the  Earl  of  Murray's  tomb"  ^  This  part  of 
the  church,  being  the  transept,  must  have  remained  open  during  the 
day,  as  appears  from  the  various  allusions  to  the  Regent's  tomb  as  a  place 
of  resort.  A  Popish  writer.  Father  Alexander  Baillie,  of  the  order  of  St.

St.  Giles,  &c.,"  in  which  he  says,  that  this  "  our  politician  apostle  and  apos- 
tate Knox,  .  .  .  provoked  the  furious  people  by  his  own  sacrilegious 
example  to  the  spoiling  and  douncasting  of  churches,  overthrowing  of 
altars  and  organs,  breaking  of  images,  chalices,  chandlers,  basines,  lauers,

children."  This  author  seems  not  to  have  been  aware  of  the  state  in  which

of  theeves  ;'  how,  I  pray  you,  wold  he  say,  if  he  were  now  entring  in  at  S. 
Giles,  and  looking  to  bare  wals  and  pillars  al  cled  with  dust,  sweepings,  and 
cobwebs,  instead  of  painting  and  tapestrie  ;  and  on  every  side  beholding  the 
restless  resorting  of  people  treating  of  their  worldly  effaires  ;  some  writing 
and  making  obligations,  contracts,  and  discharges  ;  others  laying  countes  or 
telling  over  soumes  of  money  ;  and  two  and  two  walking  and  talking  to  and 
fro,  some  about  merchandice  or  the  lawes,  and  too  many,  alias,  about  drink- 
ing and  courting  of  women,  3'ea,  and  perhaps  about  worse  nor  I  can  ima- 
gine, as  is  wont  to  be  done  al  the  day  long  in  the  common  E.xchanges  of

called  the  Low  Tolbooth,  where  the  Bailiues  of  the  Toune  use  to  sit,  and

liv  HISTORICAL  NOTICES  OF 

cages  for  scolds,  .  .  .  how  heavily  wold  He  complaine,  that  they  have 
made  his  house  not  only  a  denne  of  theeves,  bot  a  dungeon  of  devils  ;  and 
wold  weep  upon  Edinburgh,  as  he  did  on  Jerusalem,  saying,"  &c.^ 

There  was  much  truth  in  this  statement,  as  might  be  shown  from  the 
Council  Registers.  It  would,  however,  be  in  vain  to  aim  at  pointing  out 
all  the  internal  changes  made  in  this  church  during  the  two  following  cen- 
turies. In  1580,  the  city  had  three  ministers,  and  some  years  later  a  fourth 
was  added.  But  the  Presbytery,  or  ministers  of  Edinburgh,  deemed  it  ad- 
visable that  the  town  should  be  subdivided  into  Parishes  ;  and  in  April  1595, 
the  Synod  of  Lothian  and  Tweeddale  appointed  some  of  their  brethren  "  to 
travel  with  the  said  Kirk  and  Council  of  Edinburgh,  that  the  congregation 
thereof  may  be  divided  in  several  flocks,  that  every  pastor  may  know 
their  own  flock."  This  scheme  was  at  last  successful,  and  the  town  was 
divided  into  four  quarters  or  parishes.  A  subsequent  proposal  to  increase 
this  division  to  eight  parishes^  was  not  sanctioned;  but  on  the  18th  of 
April  1598,  four  additional  ministers  were  chosen,  two  for  each  quarter, 
and  the  following  arrangements  made,  by  which  the  parishioners  of  the 
north-east  quarter  resorted  to  the  (Trinity)  College  Kirk ;  of  the  south- 
east, to  the  Great  Kirk  of  St.  Giles  ;  of  the  south-west,  to  the  Upper 
Tolbooth  ;  and  of  the  north-east  quarter,  to  the  East  or  Little  Kirk.' 
Some  disputes  arose  regarding  the  latter  Kirk  ;  but  on  the  1st  of 
August  1599,  the  King  and  Privy  Council  gave  permission  to  the  Pro- 
vost, Bailies  and  Counsell  of  Edinburgh  "  to  demolishe  the  wall  biggit 
betwixt  the  East  kirk  and  the  Mid  kirk  of  Sanct  Geillis,  and  to  take  in  a 
piller  of  the  same  Mid  kirk  and  adjoyne  the  same  to  the  East  kirk,  that  it 
may  be  the  mair  able  to  hald  the  haill  parochynaris  of  that  quarter;  "*  the 
former  arrangements  of  the  two  churches  to  be  restored  when  it  shall  please 
his  Majesty,  upon  ten  days'  intimation.  Calderwood  states,  that  the  East 
Kirk  was  thus  enlarged  about  the  beginning  of  April  1600.^    According  to

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  Iv 

Eow/  Edinburgh,  in  1630,  had  four  churches,  with  eight  ministers:  those 
churches  were  the  South- West  or  Grayfriars'  kirk,  the  Great  Kii'k  or  St. 
GeiUis  kirk,  the  Little  Kirk  of  St.  Geilis  or  the  Easter  kirk,  and  the  North- 
East  or  College  kirk.  Charles  the  First,  in  his  zeal  for  Episcopacy,  erected 
Edinburgh  into  a  See  on  the  29th  of  September  1633,  and  by  a  royal  letter, 
dated  the  11th  of  October,  directed  the  Council  to  have  St.  Giles  con- 
verted into  a  Cathedral  Church,  "  according  to  the  first  intention  of  the 
erectors  and  founders  thairof,"  by  the  removal  of  various  walls  and  parti- 
tions." In  the  further  prosecution  of  this  design,  on  the  10th  of  February 
1636,  James  Hanna,  Dean  of  St.  Giles,  was  ordered  to  repair  to  Durham, 
"  to  take  a  draught  (or  plan)  of  the  Choir  of  the  Cathedral  Church  in  that 
city,  in  order  to  fit  up  and  beautify  the  inside  of  St.  Giles's  Church  after  the 
same  manner."^  The  tumult  which  took  place  within  its  walls  upon  the  first 
reading  of  the  English  service,  and  subsequent  events,  restored  the  church 
for  Presbyterian  worship.  Dr.  William  Forbes  was  the  first  Bishop  of 
Edinburgh,  but,  unlike  his  namesake,  the  first  Provost  of  this  Collegiate 
Church,  he  did  not  long  enjoy  his  Episcopal  preferment.  His  patent  is 
dated  on  the  2d  of  January  1634,  and  he  died  on  the  1st  of  April  following. 
His  successor,  David  Lindesay,  was  translated  from  Brechin  in  1(J34,  but 
was  deposed  by  the  General  Assembly  at  Glasgow  in  1638.  In  December 
1656,  the  East  Kirk  of  St.  Giles,  according  to  Nicoll,  being  again  divided, 
the  eastmost  kirk  of  the  two  was  first  completed,  and  then  occupied.  But 
within  four  years  further  changes  were  made,  for  the  same  contemporary 
authority  says,^  "This  yeir  1660,  the  twa  eistmest  kirkes  of  Edinburgh 
nerrest  the  great  old  kirk  of  St.  Geill,  were  alterit ;  the  stane  werk  and 
devisioun  betwixt  thame  wer  alterit  and  takin  doun,  with  thair  loftis  and  haill 
frame,  and  these  two  kirkis,  being  formerlie  twa  kirkes,  wer  now  erectit  in 
one  kirk  ;  the  Kingis  saitt  placed  thairin,  dasses,  saittes,  and  loftis  iiilairged 
for  ease  of  his  Majesteis  Commissioner,  and  of  the  nobles  and  utheris  of  the 
Parliament  now  convenit  to  be  haldin  the  first  day  of  Januar  nixt."     After

the  Restoration,  Episcopacy  being  again  introduced,  George  Wishart,  the 
historian  of  Montrose's  Wars,  was  appointed  Bishop  of  Edinburgh  in 
1662.  He  died  in  1671,  and  was  succeeded  by  Alexander  Young,  who  was 
translated  to  Ross  in  1679,  to  make  room  for  John  Paterson,  who  became 
Archbishop  of  Glasgow  in  1687.  Alexander  Rose,  the  last  of  this  race  of 
Prelates,  was  ejected  at  the  Revolution  in  1688.  Father  Augustine  Haj- 
says,  "  Whilst  I  was  young,  St  Giles  was  divided  into  three,  viz.,  the  New 
Church,  whereof  the  first  minister  was  named  Dean,  the  Old  Church,  and 
the  Tolbooth  Church.  Since  the  Prince  of  Orange  mastered  Scotland, 
there  is  a  new  division  ;  the  fourth  part  is  called  the  North  Church."'  This 
fourth  church  was  commonly  known  as  the  Little  Kirk,  or  Haddo's  Hole, 
and  formed  the  north-west  division  of  the  building. 

The  remarks  which  have  incidentally  been  made,  might  suggest  the 
conclusion  that  the  internal  changes  had  destroyed  the  original  design  and 
proportions  of  St.  Giles's  Church.  The  building  of  parapet  walls,  and  the 
removal  of  others,  with  the  numerous  subdivisions,  no  doubt  prevented  the 
form  of  the  building  from  being  easily  recognised  ;  still  its  mediaeval  charac- 
ter was  not  destroyed,  and  it  only  remained  for  an  architect  skilled  in  Gothic 
architectui-e,  and  embued  with  true  taste  and  feeling,  to  render  such  a  build- 
ing worthy  of  the  metropolis  of  Scotland.  Mr.  Rickman,  who  was  at  least  free 
from  all  local  prejudices  or  feelings,  and  was  familiar  with  the  finest  remains 
of  English  ecclesiastical  architecture,  in  his  notice  of  St.  Giles,  says,  "  The 
exterior  appearance  of  the  church  is  much  deteriorated  by  its  windows 
being  despoiled  of  tracerj",  the  destruction  of  battlements,  parapets,  and 
pinnacles,  and  various  modern  alterations,  but  it  is  in  contemplation  to  re- 
store it,  and  of  this  it  is  very  capable,  as  the  substantial  part  of  the  building 
is  not  much  injured,  and  if  the  interior  divisions  were  cleared,  it  would  make 
one  or  even  two  very  fine  churches."-     On  the  ground-plan,  it  would  not  be

difficult  to  point  out  that  in  its  arrangements  tlie  proper  rules  of  geometri- 
cal construction  had  been  rigidly  followed,*  thus  admitting  the  successive 
enlargements  of  the  transept  and  chancel,  and  the  addition  of  side  aisles 
and  chapels  in  conformity  with  such  rules.^  In  connexion  with  the  ground- 
plan  inserted  at  the  close  of  these  Notices,  the  following  description  given 
by  Arnot  in  the  year  1779,'  may  be  quoted,  as  it  shows  the  several  purposes 
to  which  the  building  was  appropriated. 

"  The  Church  of  St.  Giles  is  a  beautiful  Gothick  building,  in  length  from 
east  to  west,  on  the  outside  of  the  waO,  two  hundred  and  six  feet.  Its  breadth,  a( 
the  west  end,  is  one  hundred  and  ten  feet,  in  the  middle,  a  hundred  and  twenty-nine 
feet,  but  at  the  east  end,  only  seventy-six.  It  is  adorned  with  a  lofty  square  tower,  the 
top  of  which  is  encircled  with  open  figured  stone  work,  resembling  the  ornaments  that 
enrich  the  circlet  of  an  imperial  crown.  From  each  side  and  each  corner  of  the  tower, 
rises  a  slip  of  stone-work,  which,  meeting  in  the  top  with  that  which  springs  from 
the  opposite  side  forms  four  arches  intersecting  each  other,  and  compleating  the  figure  of 
an  imperial  crown,  the  top  of  which  terminates  in  a  pointed  spire.  The  church  is  built 
on  a  very  elevated  situation,  and  the  height  of  the  spire  is  a  hundred  and  sixty-one  feet. 

"  At  the  Reformation,  this  Church  was,  for  the  greater  commodiousness,  divided  by 
partition-walls.  The  four  principal  apartments  are  allotted  for  divine  worship ;  the 
lesser  ones  to  other  purposes.  The  chief  of  these  divisions  is  called  the  New  Church. 
It  is  formed  out  of  the  choir  of  St.  Giles's.  In  it  are  the  King's  seat,  those  of  the  Lord 
Provost  and  Magistrates,  and  of  the  Judges  of  the  Court  of  Session,  this  being  the  prin- 
cipal church  in  the  city. 

The  Old  Chuech. 

"  The  central  part  of  St.  Giles  is  fitted  up  as  a  place  of  worship,  for  the  accommo- 
dation of  the  citizens,  and  called  the  Old  Church. 

The  Tolbooth  Church. 
"  Upon  the  Reformation,  tbe  Presbyterians  conceived  an  immoderate  aversion  at 
bestowing  the  names  of  any  of  the  saints  upon  their  churches  ;  but  distinguished  them 
by  some  circumstance  respecting  the  time  or  manner  of  erection,  of  vicinity,  &c.  This 
church  accordingly,  which  occupies  the  south-west  quarter  of  St.  Giles's,  from  its  vicinity 
to  the  prison-house,  was  termed  the  Tolbooth  Church.

HaddoVs-Hole  Church. 

"  This  occupies  the  north-west  part  of  St.  Giles's.  It  was  not  fitted  up  as  a  place 
of  worship  till  a.d.  1699.  It  takes  the  name  of  Haddoiv's-hole,  from  its  having  been 
made  a  prison,  in  which  a  gentleman  of  the  name  of  Haddow  was  long  confined. 

"  Besides  these  churches,  the  smaller  apartments  in  this  cathedral  are  appropriated 
to  several  purposes.  The  chief  of  them  is  fitted  up  for  the  General  Assembly.  A  throne 
is  erected  in  it  for  his  Majesty's  Commissioner.  The  Convention  of  Eoyal  Burghs  is  also 
held  in  this  apartment.  In  other  parts  of  this  church,  the  City  Clerks  of  Edinburgh, 
and  the  Kirk-Session  Clerks,  have  their  offices ;  and  one  of  the  rooms  is  used  as  the  city- 
cartulary  [charter  room]  of  Edinburgh." 

Several  external  chanf^es  or  repairs  had  been  made  on  the  walls,  doors, 
and  windows,  prior  to  the  close  of  the  last  century.  The  most  important 
change  was  probably  that  which  took  place  in  the  year  1560,  by  converting 
the  western  portion  of  the  church,  with  some  additions,  into  a  Tolbooth  or 
Court  of  Justice,  and  the  eastern  portion  into  a  School.'  But  want  of 
space  prevents  any  further  notice  being  taken  of  subsequent  repairs  and 
alterations,  except  to  state  that  in  the  year  1648,  the  steeple  required  also  to 
be  in  part  rebuilt."  In  all  the  changes,  however,  which  the  building  underwent 
during  a  period  of  more  than  six  centuries,  the  old  Norman  doorway  on  the 
north  remained  entire.  From  the  Council  Records,  30th  July  1760,  we  find 
it  was  represented  "  that  the  walls  of  the  church  commonly  called  Haddo's 
Hole  were  very  himgrie,  and  ought  to  be  pointed  ;  "  and  this  was  authorized 
to  be  done  without  loss  of  time,  in  "  the  most  frugal  manner."  In  the  fol- 
lowing year  some  other  necessary  improvements  were  in  progress,  according 
to  a  plan  exhibited  to  the  Council,  and  these  were  directed  to  be  done,  still  in 
"  the  most  frugal  manner."  But  it  seems  to  have  been  in  the  year  1798,  when 
some  alterations  were  made  upon  the  vestry  of  Haddo's  Hole  or  New  North 
Church,  that  the  original  Norman  doorway  fell  a  sacrifice  to  that  indifiference 
to  what  was  venerable  for  its  antiquity,  which  then  unhappily  prevailed. 

It  might  be  out  of  place  to  describe  the  various  buildings  which  sur- 
rounded St.  Giles's  Church  as  they  appeared  in  the  earlier  part  of  the  present 
century,  before  the  demon-spirit  of  improvement  had  taken  possession  of

THE  CHURCH  OF  ST.  GILES.  lix 

the  inhabitants  of  Edinburgh.*  There  is  not  perhaps  a  city  in  Europe,  that 
has  been  so  singularly  unfortunate  in  having  its  most  venerable  public 
buildings  ruined  or  destroyed,  and  its  picturesque  old  houses  swept  away, 
in  the  course  of  modern  improvements.  The  first  false  step  consisted  in 
changing  the  external  character  of  the  Parliament  House,  erected  in  the 
reign  of  Charles  the  First.  This  building  was  commenced  in  1631,  and 
completed  in  1640,  at  an  expense  of  £11, 600  sterling.  "No  one,"  says 
Lord  Cockburn,  "  who  remembers  the  old  exterior,  can  see  the  new  one 
without  sorrow  and  indignation."'  But  while  the  High  Street  was  improved 
by  the  gradual  removal  of  the  Luckenbooths,  or  pile  of  buildings  to  the 
north  of  the  church,  and  of  the  Old  Tolbooth  or  Jail,  immortalized  as  the 
"  Heart  of  Mid-Lothian,"  and  by  the  demolition  of  the  houses  in  Forrester's 
Wynd,  and  other  tenements  on  the  west,  including  the  Council  Chambers 
and  the  Goldsmiths  Hall,  as  well  as  the  numerous  booths  or  shops  erected 
between  the  buttresses,  both  on  the  south  and  north  sides  of  the  church, 
the  building  itself,  having  escaped  the  great  fires  of  1824,  remained,  it  is 
true,  a  somewhat  unsightly  object,  but  capable,  in  competent  hands,  of  any 
improvement. 

In  the  year  1817  or  1818,  when  plans  for  the  restoration  of  this  Church 
by  Mr.  Archibald  Elliot,  architect,  were  prepared,  and  exhibited  by  the 
Town  Council,  it  was  objected,  that  this  was  "  an  original  building  in  the 
school  of  Mr.  Elliot,  not  a  renovation  of  the  ancient  building,  and  that  the 
regularity  of  the  plan  gave  it  too  much  the  character  of  an  enlarged  modern 
chapel."  From  the  notices  given  of  these  plans,  it  is  evident  that  all  the 
most  objectionable  parts  are  slavishly  copied  in  the  actual  i-enovation  which

resemblance  to  the  ancient  edifice,  consisted  at  least  of  the  most  simple  and 
appropriate  mode  of  division  of  the  building  into  an  East  and  West  Church, 
with  the  transept  as  a  great  hall  for  the  meetings  of  the  General  Assembly. 
When  the  church  was  remodelled,  the  Preston  Aisle  was  assigned  for  this 
purpose,  but  it  proved  so  unsuitable,  that  it  had  to  be  abandoned,  and  con- 
verted into  a  church,  for  which  it  was  not  much  better  adapted.  It  cannot 
therefore  cease  to  be  a  matter  of  deep  and  unavailing  regret,  that  when  in 
1829  it  was  resolved  to  improve  St.  Giles,  the  architect  had  not  been  expressly 
restricted  to  lopping  off  all  modern  excrescences,  and  to  such  restorations 
as  might  be  required,  in  conformity  to  the  original  style  of  the  building. 
But  the  genius  of  the  architect  was  not  to  be  trammelled  with  preserving 
what  remained  of  the  stone  traceries  of  old  windows,  or  carved  niches  and 
canopies,  or  antique  turrets  ;  while  aisles  or  chapels  with  lofty  vaulted 
ceilings,  ornamented  bosses,  and  groined  ribs,  however  imposing,  were  bv 
no  means  so  convenient  as  they  would  be  when  separated  into  an  upper 
and  under  apartment,  for  holding  heating  apparatus  and  for  other  purposes  ; 
and  deep,  recessed  porches,  with  rich  groinings,  although  highly  pictur- 
esque, were  not  to  be  compared  with  the  three  doorways,  or  principal 
entrances,  all  of  one  pattern,  on  which  large  windows  might  be  supported. 
It  might  otherwise,  at  a  comparatively  moderate  expense,  have  been  con- 
verted into  one  principal  church,  and  an  Assembly  Hall,  and  have  preserved 
our  venerable  Collegiate  Church  to  the  delight  of  many  generations  as  one 
of  the  finest  objects  in  Edinburgh.  Instead  however  of  directing  its 
restoration,  as  formerly,  in  "the  most  frugal  manner,"  in  addition  to  what 
the  city  funds  could  advance.  Government  was,  unluckily,  induced  to  con- 
tribute the  sum  of  £12,600  in  order  to  have  the  building  renovated  in 
the  most  approved  and  fashionable  style  of  modern  Gothic  architecture ;' 
and  OUR  ancient  venerable  church  was  renovated  with  a  ven- 
geance. Not  a  single  ancient  monument  now  exists  within  the  walls; 
all  the  beautiful  details  and  decorations  were  disregarded  ;  and,  externally, 
with  the  exception  of  the  steeple,   it  may  be  said  that  not  one  stone,  or 

'  The  entire  sum  eipeniled  in  this  unfortunate  restoration  amounted  to  £20,843,  179.  lOd. 


THE  CHURCH  OF  ST  GILES.  Ixi 

window,  of  the  old  edifice  was  allowed  to  remain.  When  Rickman  there- 
fore says,  "There  are  several  ancient  monuments  in  this  church,"'  it  may  be 
asked,  What  became  of  them  ?  In  short,  although  a  parish  or  collegiate 
church  can  never  be  compared  with  a  great  cathedral  erected  during  the 
best  times  of  Gothic  architecture,  it  is  no  improbable  supposition,  that  had 
St.  Mungo's  Cathedral  in  the  west  been  renovated  on  the  same  principle, 
Glasgow  might  now  have  had  plaster  and  whitewash  instead  of  stone,  the 
floor  reduced  to  one  level,  the  Lady  Chapel  removed  as  an  incumbrance, 
the  glorious  Crypt,  as,  strange  to  say,  it  was  in  our  own  days,  again  filled 
with  earth,  and  the  Nave  disfigured  with  pews  and  galleries.  In  some  other 
locality,  the  Church  of  St.  Giles,  as  it  now  exists,  might  have  been  orna- 
mental ;  but  it  is  no  longer  the  historical  church  where  Knox  preached, 
where  the  General  Assemblies  from  the  period  of  the  Reformation  had 
usually  held  their  meetings,  in  which  so  many  stirring  events  were  trans- 
acted, and  in  and  around  which  the  mortal  remains  of  our  most  distin- 
guished citizens,  and  of  many  generations,  had  been  deposited.  An  eloquent 
modern  writer,  in  allusion  to  such  restorations,  says,  "  By  the  exertion 
of  great  national  powers,  and  under  the  guidance  of  enlightened  monarchs, 
we  may  raise  magnificent  temples  and  gorgeous  cities ;  we  may  furnish 
labour  for  the  idle,  and  interest  for  the  ignorant.  But  the  power  neither 
of  emperors,  nor  qiieens,  nor  kingdoms,  can  ever  print  again  upon  the  sands 
of  time  the  effaced  footsteps  of  departed  generations,  or  gather  together  from 
tlie  dust  the  stones  which  had  been  stamped  with  the  spirit  of  our  ancestors." - 

Previously  to  this  remodelling  of  the  church,  begun  in  1829  and  ended 
in  1833,  careful  plans  and  elevations  had  been  executed  by  direction  of  the 
Barons  of  Exchequer.  These  plans,  drawn  by  the  late  Mr.  John  Chalmers 
are  deposited  in  the  Office  of  H.M.  Board  of  Works  ;  and  by  the  kindness 
of  Robert  Matheson,  Esq.,  accurate  copies  on  a  reduced  scale  have  been 
made  for  the  present  volume,  in  order  to  preserve  some  record  of  the  original 

'  "  The  Opening  of  the  Ciystal  Palace  considered  in 
'  Rickman'8   "  Attempt,"   &c.,   3d  edition,   p.   365.        some  of  its  relations  to  the  prospects  of  Art.     By  Jolm 
Lond.,  1825,  8vo.  Ruskin,  M.A.,"  p.  21.     Lond.,  1854,  8vo. 


kii  HISTORICAL  NOTICES  OF  ST.  GILES. 

edifice.  The  church  had  latterly  been  subdivided  into  four  places  of  public 
worship,  besides  the  City  Clerk's  chambers,  and  the  old  Police  OflSce.  The 
references  on  the  ground-plan  are  added  to  point  out  these  several  divisions. 
We  could  have  wished  that  some  pains  had  been  taken  to  preserve  accu- 
rate views  of  the  southern  porch,  the  monuments,  and  other  interesting 
objects  which  do  not  now  exist ;  with  the  exception  of  the  round  arch  of  this 
porch,  which  is  now  rebuilt  between  the  south  pillars  of  the  centre  tower,  as 
the  entrance  to  the  Old  Church.  South  St.  Giles's  Church,  so  inappropriately 
called  Tlie  Old  Churcli,  is  formed  of  the  south  transept  connected  with 
parts  of  the  Preston  Aisle  and  of  the  chapels  of  1387  which  were  not 
demolished.  The  proper  Old  Kirk  of  St.  Giles  must  have  been  the  nave 
and  side  aisles  to  the  west  of  the  centre  tower,  running  parallel  with  the 
High  or  New  Kirk  until  it  was  subdivided,  and  portions  of  it  appropriated 
to  the  three  churches  marked  in  the  ground-plan  with  the  letters  B,  C, 
and  D. 

I  have  only  further  to  add,  that  as  an  Appendix  to  these  Notices,  there 
are  subjoined,  1.  Some  Charters  discovered  subsequent  to  the  printing  of 
the  text ;  2.  Extracts  from  the  Chamberlain  Rolls,  1389  to  1437  ;  3.  A  list 
of  the  several  Altars  erected  or  endowed  within  the  Church  prior  to  the 
Reformation  ;  4.  A  list  of  the  Prebendaries  and  other  Officials  so  far  as  their 
names  have  been  recovered  ;  and  5.  Occasional  selections  from  the  Council 
Records  of  the  City  of  Edinburgh. 

DAVID  LAING.

A  The  High  Kirk,  formerly  (1579-1787)  called  the  New  Kirk. 

B  The  Old  Kirk,  so  named  since  the  year  1689. 

C  The  Tolbooth  Kirk,  so  named  since  the  year  1689. 

D  The  Little  Kirk  or  Haddow's  Hole,  erected  in  1698,  and  then  called  the 
North  New  Kirk. 

E  The  Preston  or  Assembly  Aisle. 

(The  cross  lines  between  the  pillars  are  added  to  mark  the  party  walls 
with  which  the  building  was  partitioned  into  the  above  places  of 
worship  towards  the  close  of  the  seventeenth  century.) 

a  The  South  Porch,  with  the  Revestry,  built  in  1387,  and  latterly  the 
principal  entrance  to  the  Tolbooth  Church. 

6  1,  A  2,  A  3,  6  4,  i  5,  The  five  Chapels  built  in  1387.  At  the  west  of 
b  5,  there  was  a  side  entrance  to  the  Tolbooth  Church.  At  the  south- 
west corner  of  the  Church,  and  the  north-west  of  the  Parliament 
House,  there  was  a  covered  footpath,  which  led  to  the  Parliament 
Close,  having  on  the  right  hand  an  entrance  to  the  Council  Chambers. 

c  The  south  door  of  the  "  Old  Church,"  formerly  the  entrance  to  the  South 
Transept.  It  was  approached  by  a  flight  of  steps  from  the  Parlia- 
ment Close,  and  remained  open  during  the  day. 

(/  The  Caithness  Aisle  or  Chapel,  containing  an  Ancient  Tomb,  usually 
so  called  after  William  Sinclair,  created  Earl  of  Caithness  by  James 
the  Second  in  1455,  but  which  probably  was  not  erected  till  the  begin- 
ning of  the  sixteenth  century.  The  west  part  of  this  Aisle,  along  with 
the  South  Porch  (a),  are  now  demolished. 

e   The  Tomb  of  the  Regent,  Earl  of  Murray,  1570. 

/   The  Tomb  of  John,  fourth  Earl  of  AthoU,  1579.

Otterburn,  oflScial  of  St..  Andrews,  within  the  archdeaconry  of  Lothian,  in 
the  Confiftory  Place  of  St.  Giles — "  in  ecclefia  coUegiata  Beati  Egidii  de 
Edinburgh  loco   confiftoriali  eiufdera   Iblito  et  confueto   die   nono  menfis 
Marcii  anno  Domini  millcfimo  quadringentefirao  feptuagefimo  feptimo." 
Regijlriim  Magni  Sigilli,  lib.  xix.  no.  149. 

It  appears  that  as  early  as  the  beginning  of  the  fourteenth  century,  the 
Church  of  St.  Giles  of  Edinburgh  was  the  place  where  the  Bifliop  of  St. 
Andrews  held  the  annual  Confiftory  of  his  Clergy  within  the  Archdeaconry 
of  Lothian. 

Stattda  Ecclejiae  Scoticanae,  no.  1.59,  p.  70. 

When  King  James  III.  granted  the  office  of  flieriff  of  the  burgh  of  Edin- 
burgh to  the  Provoft,  baillies,  council,  and  community,  he  took  them  bound 
to  apply  a  portion  of  the  profits  of  the  office  to  the  celebration  of  lervicos  in 
St.  Giles — "  Tenebuntur  t.amen  dicti  prepofitus  balliui  confules  et  com- 
raunitas  didi  burgi  de  Edinburgh  et  eoruni  lucceflbres  predifti  pro  diftis 
efchaetis  amerchiamentis  et  prouentibus  di6ti  officii  vicecomitis  per  nos  eis 
conceffis  celebrari  facere  annuatim  pro  perpetuo  vnum  obitum  Mifle  de 
Requiem  Placebo  Dirige  cum  nota  in  ecclefia  coUegiata  Beati  Egidii  difti 
burgi  tercio  et  quarto  diebus  menfis  Augufti  pro  lalute  anime  quondam 
progenitoris  noftri  et  auimarum  anteceflbrum  et  fuccefibrum  noftrorum 
cum  oracionum  iuffragiis  pro  noftro  profpero  ftatu."  The  charter  is  dated 
at  Edinburgh  on  the  16.  November  1482. 

Regijtrmn  Magni  Sigilli,  lib.  xvi.  no.  57. 
[The  third  of  Auguft  was  the  anniverfary  of  the  death  of  King  James  II.  at 
Roxburgh,  fo  that  the  mafs  was  to  be  celebrated  yearly  on  the  day  and  the 
morrow  of  his  death.] 

The  feaft  of  the  dedication  of  St.  Giles's  Kirk,  celebrated  on  the  third  of

Of  these  altars  Maitland  enumerates  25  (see  extract,  p.  xxx.),  omitting  Nos.  1,  16, 
17, 19,  20,  24,  29  to  32,  34  to  37,  and  39  to  43  inclusive.  Of  others  he  makes  two  or 
more  as  follows : — No.  5  he  makes  St.  Salvator's  and  the  Holy  Cross.  No.  33  he  makes 
the  Holy  Blood,  the  Holy  Cross  of  Lucano,  and  the  Holy  Cross  of  the  Body  and  Blood 
of  Christ. 

Maitland  has  added  the  following  : — 

1.  St.  Michael  de  Monte  Tomba. 

2.  St.  Eoche  and  St.  Nicholas. 

3.  St.  Thomas  the  Martyr. 

4.  St.  Barbara. 

4.  The  Holy  Blood  and  St.  Anthony  (probably  not  distinct  from  some  of  the  above). 

5.  St.  Crispin  and  Crispinianus.
